chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 1

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 1:1
verses.text: ;) is therefore shown to be reasonable, being the shunning of what hurts; from which arises repentance for previous sins.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 1:2
verses.text: "For the fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom; good understanding is to all that do it".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 1:3
verses.text: He calls wisdom a doing, which is the fear of the Lord paving the way for wisdom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 1:4
verses.text: But if the law produces fear, the knowledge of the law is the beginning of wisdom; and a man is not wise without law.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 1:5
verses.text: Therefore those who reject the law are unwise; and in consequence they are reckoned godless (ἄθεοι).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 1:6
verses.text: Now instruction is the beginning of wisdom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 1:7
verses.text: "But the ungodly despise wisdom and instruction," saith the Scripture.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 1:8
verses.text: Let us see what terrors the law announces.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 1:9
verses.text: If it is the things which hold an intermediate place between virtue and vice, such as poverty, disease, obscurity, and humble birth, and the like, these things civil laws hold forth, and are praised for so doing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 1:10
verses.text: And those of the Peripatetic school, who introduce three kinds of good things, and think that their opposites are evil, this opinion suits.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 1:11
verses.text: But the law given to us enjoins us to shun what are in reality bad things—adultery, uncleanness, paederasty, ignorance, wickedness, soul-disease, death (not that which severs the soul from the body, but that which severs the soul from truth).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 1:12
verses.text: For these are vices in reality, and the workings that proceed from them are dreadful and terrible.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 1:13
verses.text: "For not unjustly," say the divine oracles, "are the nets spread for birds; for they who are accomplices in blood treasure up evils to themselves".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 1:14
verses.text: How, then, is the law still said to be not good by certain heresies that clamorously appeal to the apostle, who says, "For by the law is the knowledge of sin?" To whom we say, The law did not cause, but showed sin.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 1:15
verses.text: For, enjoining what is to be done, it reprehended what ought not to be done.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 1:16
verses.text: And it is the part of the good to teach what is salutary, and to point out what is deleterious; and to counsel the practice of the one, and to command to shun the other.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 1:17
verses.text: Now the apostle, whom they do not comprehend, said that by the law the knowledge of sin was manifested, not that from it it derived its existence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 1:18
verses.text: And how can the law be not good, which trains, which is given as the instructor (παιδαγωγός) to Christ, that being corrected by fear, in the way of discipline, in order to the attainment of the perfection which is by Christ? "I will not," it is said, "the death of the sinner, as his repentance".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 1:19
verses.text: Now the commandment works repentance; inasmuch as it deters from what ought not to be done, and enjoins good deeds.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 1:20
verses.text: By ignorance he means, in my opinion, death.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 1:21
verses.text: "And he that is near the Lord is full of stripes".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 1:22
verses.text: Plainly, he, that draws near to knowledge, has the benefit of perils, fears, troubles, afflictions, by reason of his desire for the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 1:23
verses.text: "For the son who is instructed turns out wise, and an intelligent son is saved from burning.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 1:24
verses.text: And an intelligent son will receive the commandments".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 1:25
verses.text: And Barnabas the apostle having said, "Woe to those who are wise in their own conceits, clever in their own eyes," added, "Let us become spiritual, a perfect temple to God; let us, as far as in us lies, practice the fear of God, and strive to keep His commands, that we may rejoice in His judgments".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 1:26
verses.text: Whence "the fear of God" is divinely said to be the beginning of wisdom.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:1
verses.text: Chapter 8—The Vagaries of Basilides and Valentinus as to Fear Being the Cause of Things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:2
verses.text: Here the followers of Basilides, interpreting this expression, say, "that the Prince, having heard the speech of the Spirit, who was being ministered to, was struck with amazement both with the voice and the vision, having had glad tidings beyond his hopes announced to him; and that his amazement was called fear, which became the origin of wisdom, which distinguishes classes, and discriminates, and perfects, and restores.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:3
verses.text: For not the world alone, but also the election, He that is over all has set apart and sent forth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:4
verses.text: And Valentinus appears also in an epistle to have adopted such views.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:5
verses.text: For he writes in these very words: "And as terror fell on the angels at this creature, because he uttered things greater than proceeded from his formation, by reason of the being in him who had invisibly communicated a germ of the supernal essence, and who spoke with free utterance; so also among the tribes of men in the world, the works of men became terrors to those who made them,—as, for example, images and statues.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:6
verses.text: And the hands of all fashion things to bear the name of God:  for Adam formed into the name of man inspired the dread attaching to the pre-existent man, as having his being in him; and they were terror-stricken, and speedily marred the work".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:7
verses.text: But there being but one First Cause, as will be shown afterwards, these men will be shown to be inventors of chatterings and chirpings.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:8
verses.text: But since God deemed it advantageous, that from the law and the prophets, men should receive a preparatory discipline by the Lord, the fear of the Lord was called the beginning of wisdom, being given by the Lord, through Moses, to the disobedient and hard of heart.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:9
verses.text: For those whom reason convinces not, fear tames; which also the Instructing Word, foreseeing from the first, and purifying by each of these methods, adapted the instrument suitably for piety.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:10
verses.text: Consternation is, then, fear at a strange apparition, or at an unlooked-for representation—such as, for example, a message; while fear is an excessive wonderment on account of something which arises or is.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:11
verses.text: They do not then perceive that they represent by means of amazement the God who is highest and is extolled by them, as subject to perturbation and antecedent to amazement as having been in ignorance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:12
verses.text: If indeed ignorance preceded amazement; and if this amazement and fear, which is the beginning of wisdom, is the fear of God, then in all likelihood ignorance as cause preceded both the wisdom of God and all creative work, and not only these, but restoration and even election itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:13
verses.text: Whether, then, was it ignorance of what was good or what was evil?  Well, if of good, why does it cease through amazement? And minister and preaching and baptism are in that case superfluous to them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:14
verses.text: And if of evil, how can what is bad be the cause of what is best? For had not ignorance preceded, the minister would not have come down, nor would have amazement seized on "the Prince," as they say; nor would he have attained to a beginning of wisdom from fear, in order to discrimination between the elect and those that are mundane.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:15
verses.text: And if the fear of the pre-existent man made the angels conspire against their own handiwork, under the idea that an invisible germ of the supernal essence was lodged within that creation, or through unfounded suspicion excited envy, which is incredible, the angels became murderers of the creature which had been entrusted to them, as a child might be, they being thus convicted of the grossest ignorance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:16
verses.text: Or suppose they were influenced by being involved in foreknowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:17
verses.text: But they would not have conspired against what they foreknew in the assault they made; nor would they have been terror-struck at their own work, in consequence of foreknowledge, on their perceiving the supernal germ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:18
verses.text: Or, finally, suppose, trusting to their knowledge, they dared (but this also were impossible for them), on learning the excellence that is in the Pleroma, to conspire against man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:19
verses.text: Furthermore also they laid hands on that which was according to the image, in which also is the archetype, and which, along with the knowledge that remains, is indestructible.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:20
verses.text: To these, then, and certain others, especially the Marcionites, the Scripture cries, though they listen not, "He that heareth Me shall rest with confidence in peace, and shall be tranquil, fearless of all evil".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:21
verses.text: What, then, will they have the law to be? They will not call it evil, but just; distinguishing what is good from what is just.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:22
verses.text: But the Lord, when He enjoins us to dread evil, does not exchange one evil for another, but abolishes what is opposite by its opposite.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:23
verses.text: Now evil is the opposite of good, as what is just is of what is unjust.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:24
verses.text: If, then, that absence of fear, which the fear of the Lord produces, is called the beginning of what is good, fear is a good thing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:25
verses.text: And the fear which proceeds from the law is not only just, but good, as it takes away evil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:26
verses.text: But introducing absence of fear by means of fear, it does not produce apathy by means of mental perturbation, but moderation of feeling by discipline.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:27
verses.text: When, then, we hear, "Honour the Lord, and be strong: but fear not another besides Him," we understand it to be meant fearing to sin, and following the commandments given by God, which is the honour that cometh from God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:28
verses.text: For the fear of God is Δέος in Greek.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:29
verses.text: But if fear is perturbation of mind, as some will have it that fear is perturbation of mind, yet all fear is not perturbation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:30
verses.text: Superstition is indeed perturbation of mind; being the fear of demons, that produce and are subject to the excitement of passion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:31
verses.text: On the other hand, consequently, the fear of God, who is not subject to perturbation, is free of perturbation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:32
verses.text: For it is not God, but falling away from God, that the man is terrified for.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:33
verses.text: And he who fears this—that is, falling into evils—fears and dreads those evils.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:34
verses.text: And he who fears a fall, wishes himself to be free of corruption and perturbation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 2:35
verses.text: "The wise man, fearing, avoids evil: but the foolish, trusting, mixes himself with it," says the Scripture; and again it says, "In the fear of the Lord is the hope of strength".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:1
verses.text: Chapter 9—The Connection of the Christian Virtues.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:2
verses.text: Such a fear, accordingly, leads to repentance and hope.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:3
verses.text: Now hope is the expectation of good things, or an expectation sanguine of absent  good; and favourable circumstances are assumed in order to good hope, which we have learned leads on to love.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:4
verses.text: Now love turns out to be consent in what pertains to reason, life, and manners, or in brief, fellowship in life, or it is the intensity of friendship and of affection, with right reason, in the enjoyment of associates.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:5
verses.text: And an associate (ἑταῖρος) is another self; just as we call those, brethren, who are regenerated by the same word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:6
verses.text: And akin to love is hospitality, being a congenial art devoted to the treatment of strangers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:7
verses.text: And those are strangers, to whom the things of the world are strange.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:8
verses.text: For we regard as worldly those, who hope in the earth and carnal lusts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:9
verses.text: "Be not conformed," says the apostle, "to this world: but be ye transformed in the renewal of the mind, that ye may prove what is that good, and acceptable, and perfect, will of God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:10
verses.text: Hospitality, therefore, is occupied in what is useful for strangers; and guests (ἐπίξενοι) are strangers (ξένοι); and friends are guests; and brethren are friends.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:11
verses.text: "Dear brother," says Homer.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:12
verses.text: Philanthropy, in order to which also, is natural affection, being a loving treatment of men, and natural affection, which is a congenial habit exercised in the love of friends or domestics, follow in the train of love.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:13
verses.text: And if the real man within us is the spiritual, philanthropy is brotherly love to those who participate, in the same spirit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:14
verses.text: Natural affection, on the other hand, is the preservation of good-will, or of affection; and affection is its perfect demonstration; and to be beloved is to please in behaviour, by drawing and attracting.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:15
verses.text: And persons are brought to sameness by consent, which is the knowledge of the good things that are enjoyed in common.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:16
verses.text: For community of sentiment (ὁμογνωμοσύνη) is harmony of opinions (συμφωνία γνωμῶν).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:17
verses.text: "Let your love be without dissimulation," it is said; "and abhorring what is evil, let us become attached to what is good, to brotherly love," and so on, down to "If it be possible, as much as lieth in you, living peaceably with all men".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:18
verses.text: Then "be not overcome of evil," it is said, "but overcome evil with good".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:19
verses.text: And the same apostle owns that he bears witness to the Jews, "that they have a zeal of God, but not according to knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:20
verses.text: For, being ignorant of God's righteousness, and seeking to establish their own, they have not submitted themselves to the righteousness of God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:21
verses.text: For they did not know and do the will of the law; but what they supposed, that they thought the law wished.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:22
verses.text: And they did not believe the law as prophesying, but the bare word; and they followed through fear, not through disposition and faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:23
verses.text: "For Christ is the end of the law for righteousness," who was prophesied by the law to every one that believeth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:24
verses.text: Whence it was said to them by Moses, "I will provoke you to jealousy by them that are not a people; and I will anger you by a foolish nation, that is, by one that has become disposed to obedience".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:25
verses.text: And by Isaiah it is said, "I was found of them that sought Me not; I was made manifest to them that inquired not after Me,"—manifestly previous to the coming of the Lord; after which to Israel, the things prophesied, are now appropriately spoken: "I have stretched out My hands all the day long to a disobedient and gainsaying people".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:26
verses.text: Do you see the cause of the calling from among the nations, clearly declared, by the prophet, to be the disobedience and gainsaying of the people? Then the goodness of God is shown also in their case.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:27
verses.text: For the apostle says, "But through their transgression salvation is come to the Gentiles, to provoke them to jealousy" and to willingness to repent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:28
verses.text: And the Shepherd, speaking plainly of those who had fallen asleep, recognises certain righteous among Gentiles and Jews, not only before the appearance of Christ, but before the law, in virtue of acceptance before God,—as Abel, as Noah, as any other righteous man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:29
verses.text: He says accordingly, "that the apostles and teachers, who had preached the name of the Son of God, and had fallen asleep, in power and by faith, preached to those that had fallen asleep before" Then he subjoins: "And they gave them the seal of preaching.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:30
verses.text: They descended, therefore, with them into the water, and again ascended.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:31
verses.text: But these descended alive, and again ascended alive.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:32
verses.text: But those, who had fallen asleep before, descended dead, but ascended alive.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:33
verses.text: By these, therefore, they were made alive, and knew the name of the Son of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:34
verses.text: Wherefore also they ascended with them, and fitted into the structure of the tower, and unhewn were built up together; they fell asleep in righteousness and in great purity, but wanted only this seal".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:35
verses.text: "For when the Gentiles, which have not the law, do by nature the things of the law, these, having not the law, are a law unto themselves," according to the apostle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:36
verses.text: As, then, the virtues follow one another, why need I say what has been demonstrated already, that faith hopes through repentance, and fear through faith; and patience and practice in these along with learning terminate in love,  which is perfected by knowledge? But that is necessarily to be noticed, that the Divine alone is to be regarded as naturally wise.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:37
verses.text: Therefore also wisdom, which has taught the truth, is the power of God; and in it the perfection of knowledge is embraced.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:38
verses.text: The philosopher loves and likes the truth, being now considered as a friend, on account of his love, from his being a true servant.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:39
verses.text: The beginning of knowledge is wondering at objects, as Plato says is in his Theaetetus; and Matthew exhorting in the Traditions, says, "Wonder at what is before you;" laying this down first as the foundation of further knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:40
verses.text: So also in the Gospel to the Hebrews it is written, "He that wonders shall reign, and he that has reigned shall rest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:41
verses.text: It is impossible, therefore, for an ignorant man, while he remains ignorant, to philosophize, not having apprehended the idea of wisdom; since philosophy is an effort to grasp that which truly is, and the studies that conduce thereto.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:42
verses.text: And it is not the rendering of one accomplished in good habits of conduct, but the knowing how we are to use and act and labour, according as one is assimilated to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:43
verses.text: I mean God the Saviour, by serving the God of the universe through the High Priest, the Word, by whom what is in truth good and right is beheld.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 3:44
verses.text: Piety is conduct suitable and corresponding to God.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 4

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 4:1
verses.text: Chapter 10—To What the Philosopher Applies Himself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 4:2
verses.text: These three things, therefore, our philosopher attaches himself to: first, speculation; second, the performance of the precepts; third, the forming of good men;—which, concurring, form the Gnostic.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 4:3
verses.text: Whichever of these is wanting, the elements of knowledge limp.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 4:4
verses.text: Whence the Scripture divinely says, "And the Lord spake to Moses, saying, Speak to the children of Israel, and thou shalt say to them, I am the Lord your God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 4:5
verses.text: According to the customs of the land of Egypt, in which ye have dwelt, ye shall not do; and according to the customs of Canaan, into which I bring you, ye shall not do; and in their usages ye shall not walk.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 4:6
verses.text: Ye shall perform My judgments, and keep My precepts, and walk in them: I am the Lord your God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 4:7
verses.text: And ye shall keep all My commandments, and do them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 4:8
verses.text: He that doeth them shall live in them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 4:9
verses.text: I am the Lord your God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 4:10
verses.text: Whether, then, Egypt and the land of Canaan be the symbol of the world and of deceit, or of sufferings and afflictions; the oracle shows us what must be abstained from, and what, being divine and not worldly, must be observed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 4:11
verses.text: And when it is said, "The man that doeth them shall live in them," it declares both the correction of the Hebrews themselves, and the training and advancement of us who are nigh: it declares at once their life and ours.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 4:12
verses.text: For "those who were dead in sins are quickened together with Christ," by our covenant.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 4:13
verses.text: For Scripture, by the frequent reiteration of the expression, "I am the Lord your God," shames in such a way as most powerfully to dissuade, by teaching us to follow God who gave the commandments, and gently admonishes us to seek God and endeavour to know Him as far as possible; which is the highest speculation, that which scans the greatest mysteries, the real knowledge, that which becomes irrefragable by reason.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 4:14
verses.text: This alone is the knowledge of wisdom, from which rectitude of conduct is never disjoined.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:1
verses.text: Chapter 11—The Knowledge Which Comes Through Faith the Surest of All.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:2
verses.text: But the knowledge of those who think themselves wise, whether the barbarian sects or the philosophers among the Greeks, according to the apostle, "puffeth up".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:3
verses.text: But that knowledge, which is the scientific demonstration of what is delivered according to the true philosophy, is founded on faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:4
verses.text: Now, we may say that it is that process of reason which, from what is admitted, procures faith in what is disputed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:5
verses.text: Now, faith being twofold—the faith of knowledge and that of opinion—nothing prevents us from calling demonstration twofold, the one resting on knowledge, the other on opinion; since also knowledge and foreknowledge are designated as twofold, that which is essentially accurate, that which is defective.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:6
verses.text: And is not the demonstration, which we possess, that alone which is true, as being supplied out of the divine Scriptures, the sacred writings, and out of the "God-taught wisdom," according to the apostle? Learning, then, is also obedience to the commandments, which is faith in God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:7
verses.text: And faith is a power of God, being the strength of the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:8
verses.text: For example, it is said, "If ye have faith as a grain of mustard, ye shall remove the mountain".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:9
verses.text: And again, "According to thy faith let it be to thee".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:10
verses.text: And one is cured, receiving healing by faith; and the dead is raised up in consequence of the power of one believing that he would be raised.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:11
verses.text: The demonstration, however, which rests on opinion is human, and is the result of rhetorical arguments or dialectic syllogisms.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:12
verses.text: For the highest demonstration, to which we have alluded, produces intelligent faith by the adducing and opening up of the Scriptures  to the souls of those who desire to learn; the result of which is knowledge (gnosis).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:13
verses.text: For if what is adduced in order to prove the point at issue is assumed to be true, as being divine and prophetic, manifestly the conclusion arrived at by inference from it will consequently be inferred truly; and the legitimate result of the demonstration will be knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:14
verses.text: When, then, the memorial of the celestial and divine food was commanded to be consecrated in the golden pot, it was said, "The omer was the tenth of the three measures".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:15
verses.text: For in ourselves, by the three measures are indicated three criteria; sensation of objects of sense, speech,—of spoken names and words, and the mind,—of intellectual objects.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:16
verses.text: The Gnostic, therefore, will abstain from errors in speech, and thought, and sensation, and action, having heard "that he that looks so as to lust hath committed adultery;" and reflecting that "blessed are the pure in heart, for they shall see God;" and knowing this, "that not what enters into the mouth defileth, but that it is what cometh forth by the mouth that defileth the man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:17
verses.text: For out of the heart proceed thoughts".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:18
verses.text: This, as I think, is the true and just measure according to God, by which things capable of measurement are measured, the decad which is comprehensive of man; which summarily the three above-mentioned measures pointed out.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:19
verses.text: There are body and soul, the five senses, speech, the power of reproduction—the intellectual or the spiritual faculty, or whatever you choose to call it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:20
verses.text: And we must, in a word, ascending above all the others, stop at the mind; as also certainly in the universe overleaping the nine divisions, the first consisting of the four elements put in one place for equal interchange: and then the seven wandering stars and the one that wanders not, the ninth, to the perfect number, which is above the nine, and the tenth division, we must reach to the knowledge of God, to speak briefly, desiring the Maker after the creation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:21
verses.text: Wherefore the tithes both of the ephah and of the sacrifices were presented to God; and the paschal feast began with the tenth day, being the transition from all trouble, and from all objects of sense.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:22
verses.text: The Gnostic is therefore fixed by faith; but the man who thinks himself wise touches not what pertains to the truth, moved as he is by unstable and wavering impulses.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:23
verses.text: It is therefore reasonably written, "Cain went forth from the face of God, and dwelt in the land of Naid, over against Eden".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:24
verses.text: Now Naid is interpreted commotion, and Eden delight; and Faith, and Knowledge, and Peace are delight, from which he that has disobeyed is cast out.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:25
verses.text: But he that is wise in his own eyes will not so much as listen to the beginning of the divine commandments; but, as if his own teacher, throwing off the reins, plunges voluntarily into a billowy commotion, sinking down to mortal and created things from the uncreated knowledge, holding various opinions at various times.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:26
verses.text: "Those who have no guidance fall like leaves".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:27
verses.text: Reason, the governing principle, remaining unmoved and guiding the soul, is called its pilot.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:28
verses.text: For access to the Immutable is obtained by a truly immutable means.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:29
verses.text: Thus Abraham was stationed before the Lord, and approaching spoke.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:30
verses.text: And to Moses it is said, "But do thou stand there with Me".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:31
verses.text: And the followers of Simon wish be assimilated in manners to the standing form which they adore.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:32
verses.text: Faith, therefore, and the knowledge of the truth, render the soul, which makes them its choice, always uniform and equable.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:33
verses.text: For congenial to the man of falsehood is shifting, and change, and turning away, as to the Gnostic are calmness, and rest, and peace.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:34
verses.text: As, then, philosophy has been brought into evil repute by pride and self-conceit, so also gnosis by false gnosis called by the same name; of which the apostle writing says, "O Timothy, keep that which is committed to thy trust, avoiding the profane and vain babblings and oppositions of science (gnosis) falsely so called; which some professing, have erred concerning the faith".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:35
verses.text: Convicted by this utterance, the heretics reject the Epistles to Timothy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:36
verses.text: Well, then, if the Lord is the truth, and wisdom, and power of God, as in truth He is, it is shown that the real Gnostic is he that knows Him, and His Father by Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 5:37
verses.text: For his sentiments are the same with him who said, "The lips of the righteous know high things".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:1
verses.text: Chapter 12—Twofold Faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:2
verses.text: Faith as also Time being double, we shall find virtues in pairs both dwelling together.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:3
verses.text: For memory is related to past time, hope to future.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:4
verses.text: We believe that what is past did, and that what is future will take place.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:5
verses.text: And, on the other hand, we love, persuaded by faith that the past was as it was, and by hope expecting the future.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:6
verses.text: For in everything love attends the Gnostic, who knows one God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:7
verses.text: "And, behold, all things which He created were very good".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:8
verses.text: He both knows and admires.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:9
verses.text: Godliness adds length of  life; and the fear of the Lord adds days.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:10
verses.text: As, then, the days are a portion of life in its progress, so also fear is the beginning of love, becoming by development faith, then love.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:11
verses.text: But it is not as I fear and hate a wild beast (since fear is twofold) that I fear the father, whom I fear and love at once.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:12
verses.text: Again, fearing lest I be punished, I love myself in assuming fear.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:13
verses.text: He who fears to offend his father, loves himself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:14
verses.text: Blessed then is he who is found possessed of faith, being, as he is, composed of love and fear.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:15
verses.text: And faith is power in order to salvation, and strength to eternal life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:16
verses.text: Again, prophecy is foreknowledge; and knowledge the understanding of prophecy; being the knowledge of those things known before by the Lord who reveals all things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:17
verses.text: The knowledge, then, of those things which have been predicted shows a threefold result—either one that has happened long ago, or exists now, or about to be.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:18
verses.text: Then the extremes either of what is accomplished or of what is hoped for fall under faith; and the present action furnishes persuasive arguments of the confirmation of both the extremes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:19
verses.text: For if, prophecy being one, one part is accomplishing and another is fulfilled; hence the truth, both what is hoped for and what is passed is confirmed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:20
verses.text: For it was first present; then it became past to us; so that the belief of what is past is the apprehension of a past event, and a hope which is future the apprehension of a future event.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:21
verses.text: And not only the Platonists, but the Stoics, say that assent is in our own power.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:22
verses.text: All opinion then, and judgment, and supposition, and knowledge, by which we live and have perpetual intercourse with the human race, is an assent; which is nothing else than faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:23
verses.text: And unbelief being defection from faith, shows both assent and faith to be possessed of power; for non-existence cannot be called privation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:24
verses.text: And if you consider the truth, you will find man naturally misled so as to give assent to what is false, though possessing the resources necessary for belief in the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:25
verses.text: "The virtue, then, that encloses the Church in its grasp," as the Shepherd says, "is Faith, by which the elect of God are saved; and that which acts the man is Self-restraint.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:26
verses.text: And these are followed by Simplicity, Knowledge, Innocence, Decorum, Love," and all these are the daughters of Faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:27
verses.text: And again, "Faith leads the way, fear upbuilds, and love perfects".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:28
verses.text: Accordingly he says, the Lord is to be feared in order to edification, but not the devil to destruction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:29
verses.text: And again, the works of the Lord—that is, His commandments—are to be loved and done; but the works of the devil are to be dreaded and not done.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:30
verses.text: For the fear of God trains and restores to love; but the fear of the works of the devil has hatred dwelling along with it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:31
verses.text: The same also says "that repentance is high intelligence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:32
verses.text: For he that repents of what he did, no longer does or says as he did.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:33
verses.text: But by torturing himself for his sins, he benefits his soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 6:34
verses.text: Forgiveness of sins is therefore different from repentance; but both show what is in our power".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:1
verses.text: Chapter 13—On First and Second Repentance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:2
verses.text: He, then, who has received the forgiveness of sins ought to sin no more.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:3
verses.text: For, in addition to the first and only repentance from sins (this is from the previous sins in the first and heathen life—I mean that in ignorance), there is forthwith proposed to those who have been called, the repentance which cleanses the seat of the soul from transgressions, that faith may be established.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:4
verses.text: And the Lord, knowing the heart, and foreknowing the future, foresaw both the fickleness of man and the craft and subtlety of the devil from the first, from the beginning; how that, envying man for the forgiveness of sins, he would present to the servants of God certain causes of sins; skilfully working mischief, that they might fall together with himself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:5
verses.text: Accordingly, being very merciful, He has vouch-safed, in the case of those who, though in faith, fall into any transgression, a second repentance; so that should any one be tempted after his calling, overcome by force and fraud, he may receive still a repentance not to be repented of.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:6
verses.text: "For if we sin wilfully after that we have received the knowledge of the truth, there remaineth no more sacrifice for sins, but a certain fearful looking for of judgment and fiery indignation, which shall devour the adversaries".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:7
verses.text: But continual and successive repentings for sins differ nothing from the case of those who have not believed at all, except only in their consciousness that they do sin.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:8
verses.text: And I know not which of the two is worst, whether the case of a man who sins knowingly, or of one who, after having repented of his sins, transgresses again.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:9
verses.text: For in the process of proof sin appears on each side,—the sin which in its commission is condemned by the worker of the iniquity, and that of the man who, foreseeing what is about to be done, yet puts his hand to it as a wickedness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:10
verses.text: And he who perchance gratifies himself in anger and pleasure, gratifies himself in he knows what; and he who, repenting of that in which he gratified himself, by rushing again into pleasure, is near neighbour to him who has sinned wilfully at first.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:11
verses.text: For one, who does again that of which he has repented,  and condemning what he does, performs it willingly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:12
verses.text: He, then, who from among the Gentiles and from that old life has betaken himself to faith, has obtained forgiveness of sins once.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:13
verses.text: But he who has sinned after this, on his repentance, though he obtain pardon, ought to fear, as one no longer washed to the forgiveness of sins.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:14
verses.text: For not only must the idols which he formerly held as gods, but the works also of his former life, be abandoned by him who has been "born again, not of blood, nor of the will of the flesh," but in the Spirit; which consists in repenting by not giving way to the same fault.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:15
verses.text: For frequent repentance and readiness to change easily from want of training, is the practice of sin again.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:16
verses.text: The frequent asking of forgiveness, then, for those things in which we often transgress, is the semblance of repentance, not repentance itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:17
verses.text: "But the righteousness of the blameless cuts straight paths," says the Scripture.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:18
verses.text: And again, "The righteousness of the innocent will make his way right".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:19
verses.text: Nay, "as a father pitieth his children, so the Lord pitieth them that fear Him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:20
verses.text: David writes, "They who sow," then, "in tears, shall reap in joy;" those, namely, who confess in penitence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:21
verses.text: "For blessed are all those that fear the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:22
verses.text: You see the corresponding blessing in the Gospel.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:23
verses.text: "Fear not," it is said, "when a man is enriched, and when the glory of his house is increased: because when he dieth he shall leave all, and his glory shall not descend after him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:24
verses.text: "But I in Thy I mercy will enter into Thy house.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:25
verses.text: I will worship toward Thy holy temple, in Thy fear: Lord, lead me in Thy righteousness".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:26
verses.text: Appetite is then the movement of the mind to or from something.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:27
verses.text: Passion is an excessive appetite exceeding the measures of reason, or appetite unbridled and disobedient to the word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:28
verses.text: Passions, then, are a perturbation of the soul contrary to nature, in disobedience to reason.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:29
verses.text: But revolt and distraction and disobedience are in our own power, as obedience is in our power.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:30
verses.text: Wherefore voluntary actions are judged.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 7:31
verses.text: But should one examine each one of the passions, he will find them irrational impulses.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 8

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 8:1
verses.text: Chapter 14—How a Thing May Be Involuntary.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 8:2
verses.text: What is involuntary is not matter for judgment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 8:3
verses.text: But this is twofold,—what is done in ignorance, and what is done through necessity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 8:4
verses.text: For how will you judge concerning those who are said to sin in involuntary modes? For either one knew not himself, as Cleomenes and Athamas, who were mad; or the thing which he does, as aeschylus, who divulged the mysteries on the stage, who, being tried in the Areopagus, was absolved on his showing that he had not been initiated.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 8:5
verses.text: Or one knows not what is done, as he who has let off his antagonist, and slain his domestic instead of his enemy; or that by which it is done, as he who, in exercising with spears having buttons on them, has killed some one in consequence of the spear throwing off the button; or knows not the manner how, as he who has killed his antagonist in the stadium, for it was not for his death but for victory that he contended; or knows not the reason why it is done, as the physician gave a salutary antidote and killed, for it was not for this purpose that he gave it, but to save.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 8:6
verses.text: The law at that time punished him who had killed involuntarily, as e.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 8:7
verses.text: g.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 8:8
verses.text: , him who was subject involuntarily to gonorrhoea, but not equally with him who did so voluntarily.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 8:9
verses.text: Although he also shall be punished as for a voluntary action, if one transfer the affection to the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 8:10
verses.text: For, in reality, he that cannot contain the generative word is to be punished; for this is an irrational passion of the soul approaching garrulity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 8:11
verses.text: "The faithful man chooses to conceal things in his spirit".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 8:12
verses.text: Things, then, that depend on choice are subjects for judgment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 8:13
verses.text: "For the Lord searcheth the hearts and reins".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 8:14
verses.text: "And he that looketh so as to lust" is judged.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 8:15
verses.text: Wherefore it is said, "Thou shalt not lust".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 8:16
verses.text: And "this people honoureth Me with their lips," it is said, "but their heart is far from Me".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 8:17
verses.text: For God has respect to the very thought, since Lot's wife, who had merely voluntarily turned towards worldly wickedness, He left a senseless mass, rendering her a pillar of salt, and fixed her so that she advanced no further, not as a stupid and useless image, but to season and salt him who has the power of spiritual perception.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:1
verses.text: Chapter 15—On the Different Kinds of Voluntary Actions, and the Sins Thence Proceeding.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:2
verses.text: What is voluntary is either what is by desire, or what is by choice, or what is of intention.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:3
verses.text: Closely allied to each other are these things—sin, mistake, crime.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:4
verses.text: It is sin, for example, to live luxuriously and licentiously; a misfortune, to wound one's friend in ignorance, taking him for an enemy; and crime, to violate graves or  commit sacrilege.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:5
verses.text: Sinning arises from being unable to determine what ought to be done, or being unable to do it; as doubtless one falls into a ditch either through not knowing, or through inability to leap across through feebleness of body.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:6
verses.text: But application to the training of ourselves, and subjection to the commandments, is in our own power; with which if we will have nothing to do, by abandoning ourselves wholly to lust, we shall sin, nay rather, wrong our own soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:7
verses.text: For the noted Laius says in the tragedy:—  "None of these things of which you admonish me have escaped me; But notwithstanding that I am in my senses, Nature compels me;"  i-e:, his abandoning himself to passion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:8
verses.text: Medea, too, herself cries on the stage:—  "And I am aware what evils I am to perpetrate, But passion is stronger than my resolutions".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:9
verses.text: Further, not even Ajax is silent; but, when about to kill himself, cries:—  "No pain gnaws the soul of a free man like dishonour.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:10
verses.text: Thus do I suffer; and the deep stain of calamity Ever stirs me from the depths, agitated By the bitter stings of rage".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:11
verses.text: Anger made these the subjects of tragedy, and lust made ten thousand others—Phaedra, Anthia, Eriphyle,—  "Who took the precious gold for her dear husband".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:12
verses.text: For another play represents Thrasonides of the comic drama as saying:—  "A worthless wench made me her slave".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:13
verses.text: Mistake is a sin contrary to calculation; and voluntary sin is crime (ἀδικία); and crime is voluntary wickedness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:14
verses.text: Sin, then, is on my part voluntary.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:15
verses.text: Wherefore says the apostle, "Sin shall not have dominion over you; for ye are not under the law, but under grace".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:16
verses.text: Addressing those who have believed, he says, "For by His stripes we were healed".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:17
verses.text: Mistake is the involuntary action of another towards me, while a crime (ἀδικία) alone is voluntary, whether my act or another's.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:18
verses.text: These differences of sins are alluded to by the Psalmist, when he calls those blessed whose iniquities (ἀνομίας) God hath blotted out, and whose sins (ἁμαρτίας) He hath covered.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:19
verses.text: Others He does not impute, and the rest He forgives.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:20
verses.text: For it is written, "Blessed are they whose iniquities are forgiven, whose sins are covered.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:21
verses.text: Blessed is the man to whom the Lord will not impute sin, and in whose mouth there is no fraud".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:22
verses.text: This blessedness came on those who had been chosen by God through Jesus Christ our Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:23
verses.text: For "love hides the multitude of sins".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:24
verses.text: And they are blotted out by Him "who desireth the repentance rather than the death of a sinner".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:25
verses.text: And those are not reckoned that are not the effect of choice; "for he who has lusted has already committed adultery," it is said.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:26
verses.text: And the illuminating Word forgives sins: "And in that time, saith the Lord, they shall seek for the iniquity of Israel, and it shall not exist; and the sins of Judah, and they shall not be found".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:27
verses.text: "For who is like Me? and who shall stand before My face? You see the one God declared good, rendering according to desert, and forgiving sins.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:28
verses.text: John, too, manifestly teaches the differences of sins, in his larger Epistle, in these words: "If any man see his brother sin a sin that is not unto death, he shall ask, and he shall give him life: for these that sin not unto death," he says.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:29
verses.text: For "there is a sin unto death: I do not say that one is to pray for it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:30
verses.text: All unrighteousness is sin; and there is a sin not unto death".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:31
verses.text: David, too, and Moses before David, show the knowledge of the three precepts in the following words: "Blessed is the man who walks not in the counsel of the ungodly;" as the fishes go down to the depths in darkness; for those which have not scales, which Moses prohibits touching, feed at the bottom of the sea.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:32
verses.text: "Nor standeth in the way of sinners," as those who, while appearing to fear the Lord, commit sin, like the sow, for when hungry it cries, and when full knows not its owner.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:33
verses.text: "Nor sitteth in the chair of pestilences," as birds ready for prey.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:34
verses.text: And Moses enjoined not to eat the sow, nor the eagle, nor the hawk, nor the raven, nor any fish without scales.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:35
verses.text: So far Barnabas.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:36
verses.text: And I heard one skilled in such matters say that "the counsel of the ungodly" was the heathen, and "the way of sinners" the Jewish persuasion, and explain "the chair of pestilence" of heresies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:37
verses.text: And another said, with more propriety, that the first blessing was assigned to those who had not followed wicked sentiments which revolt from God; the second to those who do not remain in the wide and broad road, whether they be those who have been brought up in the law, or Gentiles who have repented.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:38
verses.text: And "the chair of pestilences" will be the theatres and tribunals, or rather the compliance with wicked and deadly powers, and complicity with their deeds.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:39
verses.text: "But his delight is in the law of the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:40
verses.text: Peter in his Preaching  called the Lord, Law and Logos.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:41
verses.text: The legislator seems to teach differently the interpretation of the three forms of sin—understanding by the mute fishes sins of word, for there are times in which silence is better than speech, for silence has a safe recompense; sins of deed, by the rapacious and carnivorous birds.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:42
verses.text: The sow delights in dirt and dung; and we ought not to have "a conscience" that is "defiled".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:43
verses.text: Justly, therefore, the prophet says, "The ungodly are not so: but as the chaff which the wind driveth away from the face of the earth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:44
verses.text: Wherefore the ungodly shall not stand in the judgment" (being already condemned, for "he that believeth not is condemned already"), "nor sinners in the counsel of the righteous," inasmuch as they are already condemned, so as not to be united to those that have lived without stumbling.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:45
verses.text: "For the Lord knoweth the way of the righteous; and the way of the ungodly shall perish".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:46
verses.text: Again, the Lord clearly shows sins and transgressions to be in our own power, by prescribing modes of cure corresponding to the maladies; showing His wish that we should be corrected by the shepherds, in Ezekiel; blaming, I am of opinion, some of them for not keeping the commandments.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:47
verses.text: "That which was enfeebled ye have not strengthened," and so forth, down to, "and there was none to search out or turn away".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:48
verses.text: For "great is the joy before the Father when one sinner is saved," saith the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:49
verses.text: So Abraham was much to be praised, because "he walked as the Lord spake to him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:50
verses.text: Drawing from this instance, one of the wise men among the Greeks uttered the maxim, "Follow God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:51
verses.text: "The godly," says Esaias, "framed wise counsels".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:52
verses.text: Now counsel is seeking for the right way of acting in present circumstances, and good counsel is wisdom in our counsels.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:53
verses.text: And what? Does not God, after the pardon bestowed on Cain, suitably not long after introduce Enoch, who had repented? showing that it is the nature of repentance to produce pardon; but pardon does not consist in remission, but in remedy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:54
verses.text: An instance of the same is the making of the calf by the people before Aaron.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:55
verses.text: Thence one of the wise men among the Greeks uttered the maxim, "Pardon is better than punishment;" as also, "Become surety, and mischief is at hand," is derived from the utterance of Solomon which says, "My son, if thou become surety for thy friend, thou wilt give thine hand to thy enemy; for a man's own lips are a strong snare to him, and he is taken in the words of his own mouth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:56
verses.text: And the saying, "Know thyself," has been taken rather more mystically from this, "Thou hast seen thy brother, thou hast seen thy God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:57
verses.text: Thus also, "Thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and thy neighbour as thyself;" for it is said, "On these commandments the law and the prophets hang and are suspended".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:58
verses.text: With these also agree the following: "These things have I spoken to you, that My joy might be fulfilled: and this is My commandment, That ye love one another, as I have loved you".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:59
verses.text: "For the Lord is merciful and pitiful; and gracious is the Lord to all".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:60
verses.text: "Know thyself" is more clearly and often expressed by Moses, when he enjoins, "Take heed to thyself".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:61
verses.text: "By alms then, and acts of faith, sins are purged".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:62
verses.text: "And by the fear of the Lord each one departs from evil".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 9:63
verses.text: "And the fear of the Lord is instruction and wisdom".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 10

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 10:1
verses.text: Chapter 16—How We are to Explain the Passages of Scripture Which Ascribe to God Human Affections.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 10:2
verses.text: Here again arise the cavillers, who say that joy and pain are passions of the soul: for they define joy as a rational elevation and exultation, as rejoicing on account of what is good; and pity as pain for one who suffers undeservedly; and that such affections are moods and passions of the soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 10:3
verses.text: But we, as would appear, do not cease in such matters to understand the Scriptures carnally; and starting from our own affections, interpret the will of the impassible Deity similarly to our perturbations; and as we are capable of hearing; so, supposing the same to be the case with the Omnipotent, err impiously.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 10:4
verses.text: For the Divine Being cannot be declared as it exists: but as we who are fettered in the flesh were able to listen, so the prophets spake to us; the Lord savingly accommodating Himself to the weakness of men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 10:5
verses.text: Since, then, it is the will of God that he, who is obedient to the commands and repents of his sins should be saved, and we rejoice on account of our salvation, the Lord, speaking by the prophets, appropriated our joy to Himself;  as speaking lovingly in the Gospel He says, "I was hungry, and ye gave Me to eat: I was thirsty, and ye gave Me to drink.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 10:6
verses.text: For inasmuch as ye did it to one of the least of these, ye did it to Me".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 10:7
verses.text: As, then, He is nourished, though not personally, by the nourishing of one whom He wishes nourished; so He rejoices, without suffering change, by reason of him who has repented being in joy, as He wished.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 10:8
verses.text: And since God pities richly, being good, and giving commands by the law and the prophets, and more nearly still by the appearance of his Son, saving and pitying, as was said, those who have found mercy; and properly the greater pities the less; and a man cannot be greater than man, being by nature man; but God in everything is greater than man; if, then, the greater pities the less, it is God alone that will pity us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 10:9
verses.text: For a man is made to communicate by righteousness, and bestows what he received from God, in consequence of his natural benevolence and relation, and the commands which he obeys.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 10:10
verses.text: But God has no natural relation to us, as the authors of the heresies will have it; neither on the supposition of His having made us of nothing, nor on that of having formed us from matter; since the former did not exist at all, and the latter is totally distinct from God unless we shall dare to say that we are a part of Him, and of the same essence as God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 10:11
verses.text: And I know not how one, who knows God, can bear to hear this when he looks to our life, and sees in what evils we are involved.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 10:12
verses.text: For thus it would turn out, which it were impiety to utter, that God sinned in certain portions, if the portions are parts of the whole and complementary of the whole; and if not complementary, neither can they be parts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 10:13
verses.text: But God being by nature rich in pity, in consequence of His own goodness, cares for us, though neither portions of Himself, nor by nature His children.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 10:14
verses.text: And this is the greatest proof of the goodness of God: that such being our relation to Him, and being by nature wholly estranged, He nevertheless cares for us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 10:15
verses.text: For the affection in animals to their progeny is natural, and the friendship of kindred minds is the result of intimacy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 10:16
verses.text: But the mercy of God is rich toward us, who are in no respect related to Him; I say either in our essence or nature, or in the peculiar energy of our essence, but only in our being the work of His will.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 10:17
verses.text: And him who willingly, with discipline and teaching, accepts the knowledge of the truth, He calls to adoption, which is the greatest advancement of all.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 10:18
verses.text: "Transgressions catch a man; and in the cords of his own sins each one is bound".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 10:19
verses.text: And God is without blame.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 10:20
verses.text: And in reality, "blessed is the man who feareth alway through piety".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 11

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 11:1
verses.text: Chapter 17—On the Various Kinds of Knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 11:2
verses.text: As, then, Knowledge (ἐπιστήμη) is an intellectual state, from which results the act of knowing, and becomes apprehension irrefragable by reason; so also ignorance is a receding impression, which can be dislodged by reason.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 11:3
verses.text: And that which is overthrown as well as that which is elaborated by reason, is in our power.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 11:4
verses.text: Akin to Knowledge is experience, cognition (εἴδησις), Comprehension (σύνεσις), perception, and Science.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 11:5
verses.text: Cognition (εἴδησις) is the knowledge of universals by species; and Experience is comprehensive knowledge, which investigates the nature of each thing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 11:6
verses.text: Perception (νόησις) is the knowledge of intellectual objects; and Comprehension (σύνεσις) is the knowledge of what is compared, or a comparison that cannot be annulled, or the faculty of comparing the objects with which Judgment and Knowledge are occupied, both of one and each and all that goes to make up one reason.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 11:7
verses.text: And Science (γνῶσις) is the knowledge of the thing in itself, or the knowledge which harmonizes with what takes place.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 11:8
verses.text: Truth is the knowledge of the true; and the mental habit of truth is the knowledge of the things which are true.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 11:9
verses.text: Now knowledge is constituted by the reason, and cannot be overthrown by another reason.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 11:10
verses.text: What we do not, we do not either from not being able, or not being willing—or both.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 11:11
verses.text: Accordingly we don't fly, since we neither can nor wish; we do not swim at present, for example, since we can indeed, but do not choose; and we are not as the Lord, since we wish, but cannot be: "for no disciple is above his master, and it is sufficient if we be as the master:" not in essence (for it is impossible for that, which is by adoption, to be equal in substance to that, which is by nature); but we are as Him only in our having been made immortal, and our being conversant with the contemplation of realities, and beholding the Father through what belongs to Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 11:12
verses.text: Therefore volition takes the precedence of all; for the intellectual powers are ministers of the Will.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 11:13
verses.text: "Will," it is said, "and thou shalt be able".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 11:14
verses.text: And in the Gnostic, Will, Judgment, and Exertion are identical.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 11:15
verses.text: For if the determinations are the same, the opinions and judgments will be the same too; so that both his words, and life, and conduct, are conformable to rule.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 11:16
verses.text: "And a right heart seeketh knowledge, and heareth it".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 11:17
verses.text: "God taught me wisdom, and I knew the knowledge of the holy".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:1
verses.text: Chapter 18—The Mosaic Law the Fountain of All Ethics, and the Source from Which the Greeks Drew Theirs.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:2
verses.text: It is then clear also that all the other virtues, delineated in Moses, supplied the Greeks with the rudiments of the whole department of morals.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:3
verses.text: I mean valour, and temperance, and wisdom, and justice, and endurance, and patience, and decorum, and self-restraint; and in addition to these, piety.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:4
verses.text: But it is clear to every one that piety, which teaches to worship and honour, is the highest and oldest cause; and the law itself exhibits justice, and teaches wisdom, by abstinence from sensible images, and by inviting to the Maker and Father of the universe.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:5
verses.text: And from this sentiment, as from a fountain, all intelligence increases.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:6
verses.text: "For the sacrifices of the wicked are abomination to the Lord; but the prayers of the upright are acceptable before Him," since "righteousness is more acceptable before God than sacrifice".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:7
verses.text: Such also as the following we find in Isaiah: "To what purpose to me is the multitude of your sacrifices? saith the Lord;" and the whole section.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:8
verses.text: "Break every bond of wickedness; for this is the sacrifice that is acceptable to the Lord, a contrite heart that seeks its Maker".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:9
verses.text: "Deceitful balances are abomination before God; but a just balance is acceptable to Him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:10
verses.text: Thence Pythagoras exhorts "not to step over the balance;" and the profession of heresies is called deceitful righteousness; and "the tongue of the unjust shall be destroyed, but the mouth of the righteous droppeth wisdom".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:11
verses.text: "For they call the wise and prudent worthless".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:12
verses.text: But it were tedious to adduce testimonies respecting these virtues, since the whole Scripture celebrates them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:13
verses.text: Since, then, they define manliness to be knowledge of things formidable, and not formidable, and what is intermediate; and temperance to be a state of mind which by choosing and avoiding preserves the judgments of wisdom; and conjoined with manliness is patience, which is called endurance, the knowledge of what is bearable and what is unbearable; and magnanimity is the knowledge which rises superior to circumstances.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:14
verses.text: With temperance also is conjoined caution, which is avoidance in accordance with reason.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:15
verses.text: And observance of the commandments, which is the innoxious keeping of them, is the attainment of a secure life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:16
verses.text: And there is no endurance without manliness, nor the exercise of self-restraint without temperance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:17
verses.text: And these virtues follow one another; and with whom are the sequences of the virtues, with him is also salvation, which is the keeping of the state of well-being.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:18
verses.text: Rightly, therefore, in treating of these virtues, we shall inquire into them all; for he that has one virtue gnostically, by reason of their accompanying each other, has them all.
