verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:19
verses.text: Self-restraint is that quality which does not overstep what appears in accordance with right reason.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:20
verses.text: He exercises self-restraint, who curbs the impulses that are contrary to right reason, or curbs himself so as not to indulge in desires contrary to right reason.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:21
verses.text: Temperance, too, is not without manliness; since from the commandments spring both wisdom, which follows God who enjoins, and that which imitates the divine character, namely righteousness; in virtue of which, in the exercise of self-restraint, we address ourselves in purity to piety and the course of conduct thence resulting, in conformity with God; being assimilated to the Lord as far as is possible for us beings mortal in nature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:22
verses.text: And this is being just and holy with wisdom; for the Divinity needs nothing and suffers nothing; whence it is not, strictly speaking, capable of self-restraint, for it is never subjected to perturbation, over which to exercise control; while our nature, being capable of perturbation, needs self-constraint, by which disciplining itself to the need of little, it endeavours to approximate in character to the divine nature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:23
verses.text: For the good man, standing as the boundary between an immortal and a mortal nature, has few needs; having wants in consequence of his body, and his birth itself, but taught by rational self-control to want few things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:24
verses.text: What reason is there in the law's prohibiting a man from "wearing woman's clothing "? Is it not that it would have us to be manly, and not to be effeminate neither in person and actions, nor in thought and word? For it would have the man, that devotes himself to the truth, to be masculine both in acts of endurance and patience, in life, conduct, word, and discipline by night and by day; even if the necessity were to occur, of witnessing by the shedding of his blood.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:25
verses.text: Again, it is said, "If any one who has newly built a house, and has not previously inhabited it; or cultivated a newly-planted vine, and not yet partaken of the fruit; or betrothed a virgin, and not yet married her;"—such the humane law orders to be relieved from military service: from military reasons in the first place, lest, bent on  their desires, they turn out sluggish in war; for it is those who are untrammelled by passion that boldly encounter perils; and from motives of humanity, since, in view of the uncertainties of war, the law reckoned it not right that one should not enjoy his own labours, and another should without bestowing pains, receive what belonged to those who had laboured.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:26
verses.text: The law seems also to point out manliness of soul, by enacting that he who had planted should reap the fruit, and he that built should inhabit, and he that had betrothed should marry: for it is not vain hopes which it provides for those who labour; according to the gnostic word: "For the hope of a good man dead or living does not perish," says Wisdom; "I love them that love me; and they who seek me shall find peace," and so forth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:27
verses.text: What then? Did not the women of the Midianites, by their beauty, seduce from wisdom into impiety, through licentiousness, the Hebrews when making war against them? For, having seduced them from a grave mode of life, and by their beauty ensnared them in wanton delights, they made them insane upon idol sacrifices and strange women; and overcome by women and by pleasure at once, they revolted from God, and revolted from the law.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:28
verses.text: And the whole people was within a little of falling under the power of the enemy through female stratagem, until, when they were in peril, fear by its admonitions pulled them back.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:29
verses.text: Then the survivors, valiantly undertaking the struggle for piety, got the upper hand of their foes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:30
verses.text: "The beginning, then, of wisdom is piety, and the knowledge of holy things is understanding; and to know the law is the characteristic of a good understanding".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:31
verses.text: Those, then, who suppose the law to be productive of agitating fear, are neither good at understanding the law, nor have they in reality comprehended it; for "the fear of the Lord causes life, but he who errs shall be afflicted with pangs which knowledge views not".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:32
verses.text: Accordingly, Barnabas says mystically, "May God who rules the universe vouchsafe also to you wisdom, and understanding, and science, and knowledge of His statutes, and patience.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:33
verses.text: Be therefore God-taught, seeking what the Lord seeks from you, that He may find you in the day of judgment lying in wait for these things".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:34
verses.text: "Children of love and peace," he called them gnostically.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:35
verses.text: Respecting imparting and communicating, though much might be said, let it suffice to remark that the law prohibits a brother from taking usury: designating as a brother not only him who is born of the same parents, but also one of the same race and sentiments, and a participator in the same word; deeming it right not to take usury for money, but with open hands and heart to bestow on those who need.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:36
verses.text: For God, the author and the dispenser of such grace, takes as suitable usury the most precious things to be found among men—mildness, gentleness, magnanimity, reputation, renown.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:37
verses.text: Do you not regard this command as marked by philanthropy? As also the following, "To pay the wages of the poor daily," teaches to discharge without delay the wages due for service; for, as I think, the alacrity of the poor with reference to the future is paralyzed when he has suffered want.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:38
verses.text: Further, it is said, "Let not the creditor enter the debtor's house to take the pledge with violence".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:39
verses.text: But let the former ask it to be brought out, and let not the latter, if he have it, hesitate.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:40
verses.text: And in the harvest the owners are prohibited from appropriating what falls from the handfuls; as also in reaping the law enjoins a part to be left unreaped; signally thereby training those who possess to sharing and to large-heartedness, by foregoing of their own to those who are in want, and thus providing means of subsistence for the poor.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:41
verses.text: You see how the law proclaims at once the righteousness and goodness of God, who dispenses food to all ungrudgingly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:42
verses.text: And in the vintage it prohibited the grape-gatherers from going back again on what had been left, and from gathering the fallen grapes; and the same injunctions are given to the olive-gatherers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:43
verses.text: Besides, the tithes of the fruits and of the flocks taught both piety towards the Deity, and not covetously to grasp everything, but to communicate gifts of kindness to one's neighbours.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:44
verses.text: For it was from these, I reckon, and from the first-fruits that the priests were maintained.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:45
verses.text: We now therefore understand that we are instructed in piety, and in liberality, and in justice, and in humanity by the law.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:46
verses.text: For does it not command the land to be left fallow in the seventh year, and bids the poor fearlessly use the fruits that grow by divine agency, nature cultivating the ground for behoof of all and sundry? How, then, can it be maintained that the law is not humane, and the teacher of righteousness? Again, in the fiftieth year, it ordered the same things to be performed as in the seventh; besides restoring to each one his own land, if from any circumstance he had parted with it in the meantime; setting bounds to the desires of those who covet possession, by measuring the period of enjoyment, and choosing that those who have paid the penalty of protracted penury should not suffer a life-long punishment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:47
verses.text: "But alms and acts of faith are royal guards, and blessing is on  the head of him who bestows; and he who pities the poor shall be blessed".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:48
verses.text: For he shows love to one like himself, because of his love to the Creator of the human race.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:49
verses.text: The above-mentioned particulars have other explanations more natural, both respecting rest and the recovery of the inheritance; but they are not discussed at present.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:50
verses.text: Now love is conceived in many ways, in the form of meekness, of mildness, of patience, of liberality, of freedom from envy, of absence of hatred, of forgetfulness of injuries.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:51
verses.text: In all it is incapable of being divided or distinguished: its nature is to communicate.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:52
verses.text: Again, it is said, "If you see the beast of your relatives, or friends, or, in general, of anybody you know, wandering in the wilderness, take it back and restore it; and if the owner be far away, keep it among your own till he return, and restore it".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:53
verses.text: It teaches a natural communication, that what is found is to be regarded as a deposit, and that we are not to bear malice to an enemy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:54
verses.text: "The command of the Lord being a fountain of life" truly, "causeth to turn away from the snare of death".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:55
verses.text: And what? Does it not command us "to love strangers not only as friends and relatives, but as ourselves, both in body and soul?" Nay more, it honoured the nations, and bears no grudge against those who have done ill.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:56
verses.text: Accordingly it is expressly said, "Thou shalt not abhor an Egyptian, for thou wast a sojourner in Egypt;" designating by the term Egyptian either one of that race, or any one in the world.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:57
verses.text: And enemies, although drawn up before the walls attempting to take the city, are not to be regarded as enemies till they are by the voice of the herald summoned to peace.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:58
verses.text: Further, it forbids intercourse with a female captive so as to dishonour her.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:59
verses.text: "But allow her," it says, "thirty days to mourn according to her wish, and changing her clothes, associate with her as your lawful wife".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:60
verses.text: For it regards it not right that this should take place either in wantonness or for hire like harlots, but only for the birth of children.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:61
verses.text: Do you see humanity combined with continence? The master who has fallen in love with his captive maid it does not allow to gratify his pleasure, but puts a check on his lust by specifying an interval of time; and further, it cuts off the captive's hair, in order to shame disgraceful love: for if it is reason that induces him to marry, he will cleave to her even after she has become disfigured.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:62
verses.text: Then if one, after his lust, does not care to consort any longer with the captive, it ordains that it shall not be lawful to sell her, or to have her any longer as a servant, but desires her to be freed and released from service, lest on the introduction of another wife she bear any of the intolerable miseries caused through jealousy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:63
verses.text: What more? The Lord enjoins to ease and raise up the beasts of enemies when labouring beneath their burdens; remotely teaching us not to indulge in joy at our neighbour's ills, or exult over our enemies; in order to teach those who are trained in these things to pray for their enemies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:64
verses.text: For He does not allow us either to grieve at our neighbour's good, or to reap joy at our neighbour's ill.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:65
verses.text: And if you find any enemy's beast straying, you are to pass over the incentives of difference, and take it back and restore it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:66
verses.text: For oblivion of injuries is followed by goodness, and the latter by dissolution of enmity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:67
verses.text: From this we are fitted for agreement, and this conducts to felicity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:68
verses.text: And should you suppose one habitually hostile, and discover him to be unreasonably mistaken either through lust or anger, turn him to goodness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:69
verses.text: Does the law then which conducts to Christ appear humane and mild? And does not the same God, good, while characterized by righteousness from the beginning to the end, employ each kind suitably in order to salvation? "Be merciful," says the Lord, "that you may receive mercy; forgive, that you may be forgiven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:70
verses.text: As ye do, so shall it be done to you; as ye give, so shall it be given to you; as ye judge, so shall ye be judged; as ye show kindness, so shall kindness be shown to you: with what measure ye mete, it shall be measured to you again".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:71
verses.text: Furthermore, the law prohibits those, who are in servitude for their subsistence, to be branded with disgrace; and to those, who have been reduced to slavery through money borrowed, it gives a complete release in the seventh year.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:72
verses.text: Further, it prohibits suppliants from being given up to punishment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:73
verses.text: True above all, then, is that oracle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:74
verses.text: "As gold and silver are tried in the furnace, so the Lord chooseth men's hearts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:75
verses.text: The merciful man is long-suffering; and in every one who shows solicitude there is wisdom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:76
verses.text: For on a wise man solicitude will fall; and exercising thought, he will seek life; and he who seeketh God shall find knowledge with righteousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:77
verses.text: And they who have sought Him rightly have found peace".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:78
verses.text: And Pythagoras seems to me, to have derived his mildness towards irrational creatures from the law.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:79
verses.text: For instance, he interdicted the immediate use of the young in the flocks of sheep, and goats, and herds of cattle, on the instant of their  birth; not even on the pretext of sacrifice allowing it, both on account of the young ones and of the mothers; training man to gentleness by what is beneath him, by means of the irrational creatures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:80
verses.text: "Resign accordingly," he says, "the young one to its dam for even the first seven days".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:81
verses.text: For if nothing takes place without a cause, and milk comes in a shower to animals in parturition for the sustenance of the progeny, he that tears that, which has been brought forth, away from the supply of the milk, dishonours nature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:82
verses.text: Let the Greeks, then, feel ashamed, and whoever else inveighs against the law; since it shows mildness in the case of the irrational creatures, while they expose the offspring of men; though long ago and prophetically, the law, in the above-mentioned commandment, threw a check in the way of their cruelty.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:83
verses.text: For if it prohibits the progeny of the irrational creatures to be separated from the dam before sucking, much more in the case of men does it provide beforehand a cure for cruelty and savageness of disposition; so that even if they despise nature, they may not despise teaching.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:84
verses.text: For they are permitted to satiate themselves with kids and lambs, and perhaps there might be some excuse for separating the progeny from its dam.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:85
verses.text: But what cause is there for the exposure of a child? For the man who did not desire to beget children had no right to marry at first; certainly not to have become, through licentious indulgence, the murderer of his children.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:86
verses.text: Again, the humane law forbids slaying the offspring and the dam together on the same day.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:87
verses.text: Thence also the Romans, in the case of a pregnant woman being condemned to death, do not allow her to undergo punishment till she is delivered.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:88
verses.text: The law too, expressly prohibits the slaying of such animals as are pregnant till they have brought forth, remotely restraining the proneness of man to do wrong to man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:89
verses.text: Thus also it has extended its clemency to the irrational creatures; that from the exercise of humanity in the case of creatures of different species, we might practice among those of the same species a large abundance of it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:90
verses.text: Those, too, that kick the bellies of certain animals before parturition, in order to feast on flesh mixed with milk, make the womb created for the birth of the foetus its grave, though the law expressly commands, "But neither shalt thou seethe a lamb in its mother's milk".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:91
verses.text: For the nourishment of the living animal, it is meant, may not become sauce for that which has been deprived of life; and that, which is the cause of life, may not co-operate in the consumption of the body.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:92
verses.text: And the same law commands "not to muzzle the ox which treadeth out the corn: for the labourer must be reckoned worthy of his food".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:93
verses.text: And it prohibits an ox and ass to be yoked in the plough together; pointing perhaps to the want of agreement in the case of the animals; and at the same time teaching not to wrong any one belonging to another race, and bring him under the yoke, when there is no other cause to allege than difference of race, which is no cause at all, being neither wickedness nor the effect of wickedness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:94
verses.text: To me the allegory also seems to signify that the husbandry of the Word is not to be assigned equally to the clean and the unclean, the believer and the unbeliever; for the ox is clean, but the ass has been reckoned among the unclean animals.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:95
verses.text: But the benignant Word, abounding in humanity, teaches that neither is it right to cut down cultivated trees, or to cut down the grain before the harvest, for mischiefs sake; nor that cultivated fruit is to be destroyed at all—either the fruit of the soil or that of the soul: for it does not permit the enemy's country to be laid waste.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:96
verses.text: Further, husbandmen derived advantage from the law in such things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:97
verses.text: For it orders newly planted trees to be nourished three years in succession, and the superfluous growths to be cut off, to prevent them being loaded and pressed down; and to prevent their strength being exhausted from want, by the nutriment being frittered away, enjoins tilling and digging round them, so that the tree may not, by sending out suckers, hinder its growth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:98
verses.text: And it does not allow imperfect fruit to be plucked from immature trees, but after three years, in the fourth year; dedicating the first-fruits to God after the tree has attained maturity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:99
verses.text: This type of husbandry may serve as a mode of instruction, teaching that we must cut the growths of sins, and the useless weeds of the mind that spring up round the vital fruit, till the shoot of faith is perfected and becomes strong.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:100
verses.text: For in the fourth year, since there is need of time to him that is being solidly catechized, the four virtues are consecrated to God, the third alone being already joined to the fourth, the person of the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:101
verses.text: And a sacrifice of praise is above holocausts: "for He," it is said, "giveth strength to get power".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:102
verses.text: And if your affairs are in the sunshine of prosperity, get and keep strength, and acquire power in knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 12:103
verses.text: For by these instances it is shown that both good things and gifts are supplied by God; and that we, becoming ministers of the divine grace, ought to sow the benefits of God, and make those who approach us noble and good; so that, as far as possible, the temperate man may make others continent, he that is manly may make them noble, he that is wise may make them intelligent, and the just may make them just.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:1
verses.text: Chapter 19—The True Gnostic is an Imitator of God, Especially in Beneficence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:2
verses.text: He is the Gnostic, who is after the image and likeness of God, who imitates God as far as possible, deficient in none of the things which contribute to the likeness as far as compatible, practising self-restraint and endurance, living righteously, reigning over the passions, bestowing of what he has as far as possible, and doing good both by word and deed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:3
verses.text: "He is the greatest," it is said, "in the kingdom who shall do and teach;" imitating God in conferring like benefits.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:4
verses.text: For God's gifts are for the common good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:5
verses.text: "Whoever shall attempt to do aught with presumption, provokes God," it is said.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:6
verses.text: For haughtiness is a vice of the soul, of which, as of other sins, He commands us to repent; by adjusting our lives from their state of derangement to the change for the better in these three things—mouth, heart, hands.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:7
verses.text: These are signs—the hands of action, the heart of volition, the mouth of speech.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:8
verses.text: Beautifully, therefore, has this oracle been spoken with respect to penitents: "Thou hast chosen God this day to be thy God; and God hath chosen thee this day to be His people".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:9
verses.text: For him who hastes to serve the self-existent One, being a suppliant, God adopts to Himself; and though he be only one in number, he is honoured equally with the people.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:10
verses.text: For being a part of the people, he becomes complementary of it, being restored from what he was; and the whole is named from a part.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:11
verses.text: But nobility is itself exhibited in choosing and practising what is best.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:12
verses.text: For what benefit to Adam was such a nobility as he had? No mortal was his father; for he himself was father of men that are born.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:13
verses.text: What is base he readily chose, following his wife, and neglected what is true and good; on which account he exchanged his immortal life for a mortal life, but not for ever.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:14
verses.text: And Noah, whose origin was not the same as Adam's, was saved by divine care.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:15
verses.text: For he took and consecrated himself to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:16
verses.text: And Abraham, who had children by three wives, not for the indulgence of pleasure, but in the hope, as I think, of multiplying the race at the first, was succeeded by one alone, who was heir of his father's blessings, while the rest were separated from the family; and of the twins who sprang from him, the younger having won his father's favour and received his prayers, became heir, and the elder served him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:17
verses.text: For it is the greatest boon to a bad man not to be master of himself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:18
verses.text: And this arrangement was prophetical and typical.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:19
verses.text: And that all things belong to the wise, Scripture clearly indicates when it is said, "Because God hath had mercy on me, I have all things".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:20
verses.text: For it teaches that we are to desire one thing, by which are all things, and what is promised is assigned to the worthy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:21
verses.text: Accordingly, the good man who has become heir of the kingdom, it registers also as fellow-citizen, through divine wisdom, with the righteous of the olden time, who under the law and before the law lived according to law, whose deeds have become laws to us; and again, teaching that the wise man is king, introduces people of a different race, saying to him, "Thou art a king before God among us;" those who were governed obeying the good man of their own accord, from admiration of his virtue.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:22
verses.text: Now Plato the philosopher, defining the end of happiness, says that it is likeness to God as far as possible; whether concurring with the precept of the law (for great natures that are free of passions somehow hit the mark respecting the truth, as the Pythagorean Philo says in relating the history of Moses), or whether instructed by certain oracles of the time, thirsting as he always was for instruction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:23
verses.text: For the law says, "Walk after the Lord your God, and keep my commandments".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:24
verses.text: For the law calls assimilation following; and such a following to the utmost of its power assimilates.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:25
verses.text: "Be," says the Lord, "merciful and pitiful, as your heavenly Father is pitiful".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:26
verses.text: Thence also the Stoics have laid down the doctrine, that living agreeably to nature is the end, fitly altering the name of God into nature; since also nature extends to plants, to seeds, to trees, and to stones.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:27
verses.text: It is therefore plainly said, "Bad men do not understand the law; but they who love the law fortify themselves with a wall".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:28
verses.text: "For the wisdom of the clever knows its ways; but the folly of the foolish is in error".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:29
verses.text: "For on whom will I look, but on him who is mild and gentle, and trembleth at my words?" says the prophecy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:30
verses.text: We are taught that there are three kinds of friendship: and that of these the first and the best is that which results from virtue, for the love that is founded on reason is firm; that the second and intermediate is by way of recompense, and is social, liberal, and useful for life; for the friendship which is the result of favour is mutual.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:31
verses.text: And the third and last we assert to be that which is founded on intimacy; others, again, that it is that variable and changeable form which rests on pleasure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:32
verses.text: And Hippodamus the Pythagorean seems to me to describe friendships most admirably: "That founded on knowledge of the gods, that founded on the gifts of men, and that on the pleasures of animals".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:33
verses.text: There is the friendship of a philosopher,—that of a man and that of an animal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:34
verses.text: For the image of God is really the man who does good, in which also he gets good: as the pilot at once saves, and is saved.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:35
verses.text: Wherefore, when one obtains his request, he does not say to the giver, Thou hast given well, but, Thou hast received well.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:36
verses.text: So he receives who gives, and he gives who receives.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:37
verses.text: "But the righteous pity and show mercy".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:38
verses.text: "But the mild shall be inhabitants of the earth, and the innocent shall be left in it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:39
verses.text: But the transgressors shall be extirpated from it".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:40
verses.text: And Homer seems to me to have said prophetically of the faithful, "Give to thy friend".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:41
verses.text: And an enemy must be aided, that he may not continue an enemy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:42
verses.text: For by help good feeling is compacted, and enmity dissolved.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:43
verses.text: "But if there be present readiness of mind, according to what a man hath it is acceptable, and not according to what he hath not: for it is not that there be ease to others, but tribulation to you, but of equality at the present time," and so forth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:44
verses.text: "He hath dispersed, he hath given to the poor; his righteousness endureth for ever," the Scripture says.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:45
verses.text: For conformity with the image and likeness is not meant of the body (for it were wrong for what is mortal to be made like what is immortal), but in mind and reason, on which fitly the Lord impresses the seal of likeness, both in respect of doing good and of exercising rule.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:46
verses.text: For governments are directed not by corporeal qualities, but by judgments of the mind.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 13:47
verses.text: For by the counsels of holy men states are managed well, and the household also.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:1
verses.text: Chapter 20—The True Gnostic Exercises Patience and Self-Restraint.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:2
verses.text: Endurance also itself forces its way to the divine likeness, reaping as its fruit impassibility through patience, if what is related of Ananias be kept in mind; who belonged to a number, of whom Daniel the prophet, filled with divine faith, was one.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:3
verses.text: Daniel dwelt at Babylon, as Lot at Sodom, and Abraham, who a little after became the friend of God, in the land of Chaldea.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:4
verses.text: The king of the Babylonians let Daniel down into a pit full of wild beasts; the King of all, the faithful Lord, took him up unharmed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:5
verses.text: Such patience will the Gnostic, as a Gnostic, possess.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:6
verses.text: He will bless when under trial, like the noble Job; like Jonas, when swallowed up by the whale, he will pray, and faith will restore him to prophesy to the Ninevites; and though shut up with lions, he will tame the wild beasts; though cast into the fire, he will be besprinkled with dew, but not consumed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:7
verses.text: He will give his testimony by night; he will testify by day; by word, by life, by conduct, he will testify.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:8
verses.text: Dwelling with the Lord he will continue his familiar friend, sharing the same hearth according to the Spirit; pure in the flesh, pure in heart, sanctified in word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:9
verses.text: "The world," it is said, "is crucified to him, and he to the world".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:10
verses.text: He, bearing about the cross of the Saviour, will follow the Lord's footsteps, as God, having become holy of holies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:11
verses.text: The divine law, then, while keeping in mind all virtue, trains man especially to self-restraint, laying this as the foundation of the virtues; and disciplines us beforehand to the attainment of self-restraint by forbidding us to partake of such things as are by nature fat, as the breed of swine, which is full-fleshed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:12
verses.text: For such a use is assigned to epicures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:13
verses.text: It is accordingly said that one of the philosophers, giving the etymology of ὗς (sow), said that it was θύς, as being fit only for slaughter (θύσιν) and killing; for life was given to this animal for no other purpose than that it might swell in flesh.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:14
verses.text: Similarly, repressing our desires, it forbade partaking of fishes which have neither fins nor scales; for these surpass other fishes in fleshiness and fatness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:15
verses.text: From this it was, in my opinion, that the mysteries not only prohibited touching certain animals, but also withdrew certain parts of those slain in sacrifice, for reasons which are known to the initiated.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:16
verses.text: If, then, we are to exercise control over the belly, and what is below the belly, it is clear that we have of old heard from the Lord that we are to check lust by the law.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:17
verses.text: And this will be completely effected, if we unfeignedly condemn what is the fuel of lust: I mean pleasure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:18
verses.text: Now they say that the idea of it is a gentle and bland excitement, accompanied with some sensation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:19
verses.text: Enthralled by this, Menelaus, they say, after the capture of Troy, having rushed to put Helen to death, as having been the cause of such calamities, was nevertheless not able to effect it, being subdued by her beauty, which made him think of pleasure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:20
verses.text: Whence the tragedians, jeering, exclaimed insultingly against him:—  "But thou, when on her breast thou lookedst, thy sword Didst cast away, and with a kiss the traitress, Ever-beauteous wretch, thou didst embrace".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:21
verses.text: And again:—  "Was the sword then by beauty blunted?"  And I agree with Antisthenes when he says, "Could I catch Aphrodite, I would shoot her; for she has destroyed many of our beautiful and good women".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:22
verses.text: And he says that "Love is a vice of nature, and the wretches who fall under its power call the disease a deity".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:23
verses.text: For in these words it is shown that stupid people are overcome from ignorance of pleasure, to which we ought to give no admittance, even though it be called a god, that is, though it be given by God for the necessity of procreation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:24
verses.text: And Xenophon, expressly calling pleasure a vice, says: "Wretch, what good dost thou know, or what honourable aim hast thou? which does not even wait for the appetite for sweet things, eating before being hungry, drinking before being thirsty; and that thou mayest eat pleasantly, seeking out fine cooks; and that thou mayest drink pleasantly, procuring costly wines; and in summer runnest about seeking snow; and that thou mayest sleep pleasantly, not only providest soft beds, but also supports to the couches".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:25
verses.text: Whence, as Aristo said, "against the whole tetrachord of pleasure, pain, fear, and lust, there is need of much exercise and struggle".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:26
verses.text: "For it is these, it is these that go through our bowels, And throw into disorder men's hearts".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:27
verses.text: "For the minds of those even who are deemed grave, pleasure makes waxen," according to Plato; since "each pleasure and pain nails to the body the soul" of the man, that does not sever and crucify himself from the passions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:28
verses.text: "He that loses his life," says the Lord, "shall save it;" either giving it up by exposing it to danger for the Lord's sake, as He did for us, or loosing it from fellowship with its habitual life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:29
verses.text: For if you would loose, and withdraw, and separate (for this is what the cross means) your soul from the delight and pleasure that is in this life, you will possess it, found and resting in the looked-for hope.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:30
verses.text: And this would be the exercise of death, if we would be content with those desires which are measured according to nature alone, which do not pass the limit of those which are in accordance with nature—by going to excess, or going against nature—in which the possibility of sinning arises.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:31
verses.text: "We must therefore put on the panoply of God, that we may be able to stand against the wiles of the devil; since the weapons of our warfare are not carnal, but mighty through God to the pulling down of strongholds, casting down reasonings, and every lofty thing which exalteth itself against the knowledge of God, and bringing every thought into captivity unto the obedience of Christ," says the divine apostle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:32
verses.text: There is need of a man who shall use in a praiseworthy and discriminating manner the things from which passions take their rise, as riches and poverty, honour and dishonour, health and sickness, life and death, toil and pleasure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:33
verses.text: For, in order that we may treat things, that are different, indifferently, there is need of a great difference in us, as having been previously afflicted with much feebleness, and in the distortion of a bad training and nurture ignorantly indulged ourselves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:34
verses.text: The simple word, then, of our philosophy declares the passions to be impressions on the soul that is soft and yielding, and, as it were, the signatures of the spiritual powers with whom we have to struggle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:35
verses.text: For it is the business, in my opinion, of the malificent powers to endeavour to produce somewhat of their own constitution in everything, so as to overcome and make their own those who have renounced them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:36
verses.text: And it follows, as might be expected, that some are worsted; but in the case of those who engage in the contest with more athletic energy, the powers mentioned above, after carrying on the conflict in all forms, and advancing even as far as the crown wading in gore, decline the battle, and admire the victors.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:37
verses.text: For of objects that are moved, some are moved by impulse and appearance, as animals; and some by transposition, as inanimate objects.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:38
verses.text: And of things without life, plants, they say, are moved by transposition in order to growth, if we will concede to them that plants are without life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:39
verses.text: To stones, then, belongs a permanent state.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:40
verses.text: Plants have a nature; and the irrational animals possess impulse and perception, and likewise the two characteristics already specified.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:41
verses.text: But the reasoning faculty, being peculiar to the human soul, ought not to be impelled similarly with the irrational animals, but ought to discriminate appearances, and not to be carried away by them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:42
verses.text: The powers, then, of which we have spoken hold out beautiful sights, and honours, and adulteries, and pleasures, and such like alluring phantasies before facile spirits; as those who drive away cattle hold out branches to them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:43
verses.text: Then, having beguiled those incapable of distinguishing the true from the false pleasure, and the fading and meretricious from the holy beauty, they lead them into slavery.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:44
verses.text: And each deceit, by pressing constantly on the spirit, impresses its image on it; and the soul unwittingly carries about the image of the passion, which takes its rise from the bait and our consent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:45
verses.text: The adherents of Basilides are in the habit of  calling the passions appendages: saying that these are in essence certain spirits attached to the rational soul, through some original perturbation and confusion; and that, again, other bastard and heterogeneous natures of spirits grow on to them, like that of the wolf, the ape, the lion, the goat, whose properties showing themselves around the soul, they say, assimilate the lusts of the soul to the likeness of the animals.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:46
verses.text: For they imitate the actions of those whose properties they bear.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:47
verses.text: And not only are they associated with the impulses and perceptions of the irrational animals, but they affect the motions and the beauties of plants, on account of their bearing also the properties of plants attached to them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:48
verses.text: They have also the properties of a particular state, as the hardness of steel.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:49
verses.text: But against this dogma we shall argue subsequently, when we treat of the soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:50
verses.text: At present this only needs to be pointed out, that man, according to Basilides, preserves the appearance of a wooden horse, according to the poetic myth, embracing as he does in one body a host of such different spirits.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:51
verses.text: Accordingly, Basilides' son himself, Isidorus, in his book, About the Soul attached to us, while agreeing in the dogma, as if condemning himself, writes in these words: "For if I persuade any one that the soul is undivided, and that the passions of the wicked are occasioned by the violence of the appendages, the worthless among men will have no slight pretence for saying, 'I was compelled, I was carried away, I did it against my will, I acted unwillingly;' though he himself led the desire of evil things, and did not fight against the assaults of the appendages.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:52
verses.text: But we must, by acquiring superiority in the rational part, show ourselves masters of the inferior creation in us".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:53
verses.text: For he too lays down the hypothesis of two souls in us, like the Pythagoreans, at whom we shall glance afterwards.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:54
verses.text: Valentinus too, in a letter to certain people, writes in these very words respecting the appendages: "There is one good, by whose presence is the manifestation, which is by the Son, and by Him alone can the heart become pure, by the expulsion of every evil spirit from the heart: for the multitude of spirits dwelling in it do not suffer it to be pure; but each of them performs his own deeds, insulting it oft with unseemly lusts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:55
verses.text: And the heart seems to be treated somewhat like a caravanserai.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:56
verses.text: For the latter has holes and ruts made in it, and is often filled with dung; men living filthily in it, and taking no care for the place as belonging to others.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:57
verses.text: So fares it with the heart as long as there is no thought taken for it, being unclean, and the abode of many demons.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:58
verses.text: But when the only good Father visits it, it is sanctified, and gleams with light.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:59
verses.text: And he who possesses such a heart is so blessed, that "he shall see God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:60
verses.text: What, then, let them tell us, is the cause of such a soul not being cared for from the beginning? Either that it is not worthy (and somehow a care for it comes to it as from repentance), or it is a saved nature, as he would have it; and this, of necessity, from the beginning, being cared for by reason of its affinity, afforded no entrance to the impure spirits, unless by being forced and found feeble.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:61
verses.text: For were he to grant that on repentance it preferred what was better, he will say this unwillingly, being what the truth we hold teaches; namely, that salvation is from a change due to obedience, but not from nature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:62
verses.text: For as the exhalations which arise from the earth, and from marshes, gather into mists and cloudy masses; so the vapours of fleshly lusts bring on the soul an evil condition, scattering about the idols of pleasure before the soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:63
verses.text: Accordingly they spread darkness over the light of intelligence, the spirit attracting the exhalations that arise from lust, and thickening the masses of the passions by persistency in pleasures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:64
verses.text: Gold is not taken from the earth in the lump, but is purified by smelting; then, when made pure, it is called gold, the earth being purified.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:65
verses.text: For "Ask, and it shall be given you," it is said to those who are able of themselves to choose what is best.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:66
verses.text: And how we say that the powers of the devil, and the unclean spirits, sow into the sinner's soul, requires no more words from me, on adducing as a witness the apostolic Barnabas (and he was one of the seventy, and a fellow-worker of Paul), who speaks in these words: "Before we believed in God, the dwelling-place of our heart was unstable, truly a temple built with hands.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:67
verses.text: For it was full of idolatry, and was a house of demons, through doing what was opposed to God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:68
verses.text: He says, then, that sinners exercise activities appropriate to demons; but he does not say that the spirits themselves dwell in the soul of the unbeliever.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:69
verses.text: Wherefore he also adds, "See that the temple of the Lord be gloriously built.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:70
verses.text: Learn, having received remission of sins; and having set our hope on the Name, let us become new, created again from the beginning".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:71
verses.text: For what he says is not that demons are driven out of us, but that the sins which like them we commit before believing are remitted.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:72
verses.text: Rightly thus he puts in opposition what follows: "Wherefore God truly dwells in our home.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:73
verses.text: He dwells in us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:74
verses.text: How? The word of His faith, the calling of His promise, the wisdom of His statutes, the  commandments of His communication, dwell in us".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:75
verses.text: "I know that I have come upon a heresy; and its chief was wont to say that he fought with pleasure by pleasure, this worthy Gnostic advancing on pleasure in feigned combat, for he said he was a Gnostic; since he said it was no great thing for a man that had not tried pleasure to abstain from it, but for one who had mixed in it not to be overcome was something; and that therefore by means of it he trained himself in it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:76
verses.text: The wretched man knew not that he was deceiving himself by the artfulness of voluptuousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:77
verses.text: To this opinion, then, manifestly Aristippus the Cyrenian adhered—that of the sophist who boasted of the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:78
verses.text: Accordingly, when reproached for continually cohabiting with the Corinthian courtezan, he said, "I possess Lais, and am not possessed by her".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:79
verses.text: Such also are those (who say that they follow Nicolaus, quoting an adage of the man, which they pervert, "that the flesh must be abused".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:80
verses.text: But the worthy man showed that it was necessary to check pleasures and lusts, and by such training to waste away the impulses and propensities of the flesh.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:81
verses.text: But they, abandoning themselves to pleasure like goats, as if insulting the body, lead a life of self-indulgence; not knowing that the body is wasted, being by nature subject to dissolution; while their soul is buried in the mire of vice; following as they do the teaching of pleasure itself, not of the apostolic man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:82
verses.text: For in what do they differ from Sardanapalus, whose life is shown in the epigram:—  "I have what I ate—what I enjoyed wantonly; And the pleasures I felt in love.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:83
verses.text: But those Many objects of happiness are left, For I too am dust, who ruled great Ninus".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:84
verses.text: For the feeling of pleasure is not at all a necessity, but the accompaniment of certain natural needs—hunger, thirst, cold, marriage.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:85
verses.text: If, then, it were possible to drink without it, or take food, or beget children, no other need of it could be shown.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:86
verses.text: For pleasure is neither a function, nor a state, nor any part of us; but has been introduced into life as an auxiliary, as they say salt was to season food.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:87
verses.text: But when it casts off restraint and rules the house, it generates first concupiscence, which is an irrational propension and impulse towards that which gratifies it; and it induced Epicurus to lay down pleasure as the aim of the philosopher.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:88
verses.text: Accordingly he deifies a sound condition of body, and the certain hope respecting it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:89
verses.text: For what else is luxury than the voluptuous gluttony and the superfluous abundance of those who are abandoned to self-indulgence? Diogenes writes significantly in a tragedy:—  "Who to the pleasures of effeminate And filthy luxury attached in heart, Wish not to undergo the slightest toil".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:90
verses.text: And what follows, expressed indeed in foul language, but in a manner worthy of the voluptuaries.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:91
verses.text: Wherefore the divine law appears to me necessarily to menace with fear, that, by caution and attention, the philosopher may acquire and retain absence of anxiety, continuing without fall and without sin in all things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:92
verses.text: For peace and freedom are not otherwise won, than by ceaseless and unyielding struggles with our lusts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:93
verses.text: For these stout and Olympic antagonists are keener than wasps, so to speak; and Pleasure especially, not by day only, but by night, is in dreams with witchcraft ensnaringly plotting and biting.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:94
verses.text: How, then, can the Greeks any more be right in running down the law, when they themselves teach that Pleasure is the slave of fear? Socrates accordingly bids "people guard against enticements to eat when they are not hungry, and to drink when not thirsty, and the glances and kisses of the fair, as fitted to inject a deadlier poison than that of scorpions and spiders".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:95
verses.text: And Antisthenes chose rather "to be demented than delighted".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:96
verses.text: And the Theban Crates says:—  "Master these, exulting in the disposition of the soul, Vanquished neither by gold nor by languishing love, Nor are they any longer attendants to the wanton".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:97
verses.text: And at length infers:—  "Those, unenslaved and unbended by servile Pleasure, Love the immortal kingdom and freedom".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:98
verses.text: He writes expressly, in other words, "that the stop to the unbridled propensity to amorousness is hunger or a halter".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:99
verses.text: And the comic poets attest, while they depreciate the teaching of Zeno the Stoic, to be to the following effect:—  "For he philosophizes a vain philosophy: He teaches to want food, and gets pupils One loaf, and for seasoning a dry fig, and to drink water".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:100
verses.text: All these, then, are not ashamed clearly to confess the advantage which accrues from caution.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:101
verses.text: And the wisdom which is true and not contrary to reason, trusting not in mere words and oracular utterances, but in invulnerable armour of defence and energetic mysteries, and devoting itself to divine commands, and exercise, and practice, receives a divine power according to its inspiration from the Word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:102
verses.text: Already, then, the aegis of the poetic Jove is described as  "Dreadful, crowned all around by Terror, And on it Strife and Prowess, and chilling Rout; On it, too, the Gorgon's head, dread monster, Terrible, dire, the sign of aegis-bearing Jove".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:103
verses.text: But to those, who are able rightly to understand salvation, I know not what will appear dearer than the gravity of the Law, and Reverence, which is its daughter.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:104
verses.text: For when one is said to pitch too high, as also the Lord says, with reference to certain; so that some of those whose desires are towards Him may not sing out of pitch and tune, I do not understand it as pitching too high in reality, but only as spoken with reference to such as will not take up the divine yoke.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:105
verses.text: For to those, who are unstrung and feeble, what is medium seems too high; and to those, who are unrighteous, what befalls them seems severe justice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:106
verses.text: For those, who, on account of the favour they entertain for sins, are prone to pardon, suppose truth to be harshness, and severity to be savageness, and him who does not sin with them, and is not dragged with them, to be pitiless.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:107
verses.text: Tragedy writes therefore well of Pluto:—  "And to what sort of a deity wilt thou come, dost thou ask, Who knows neither clemency nor favour, But loves bare justice alone".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:108
verses.text: For although you are not yet able to do the things enjoined by the Law, yet, considering that the noblest examples are set before us in it, we are able to nourish and increase the love of liberty; and so we shall profit more eagerly as far as we can, inviting some things, imitating some things, and fearing others.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:109
verses.text: For thus the righteous of the olden time, who lived according to the law, "were not from a storied oak, or from a rock;" because they wish to philosophize truly, took and devoted themselves entirely to God, and were classified under faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:110
verses.text: Zeno said well of the Indians, that he would rather have seen one Indian roasted, than have learned the whole of the arguments about bearing pain.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:111
verses.text: But we have exhibited before our eyes every day abundant sources of martyrs that are burnt, impaled, beheaded.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:112
verses.text: All these the fear inspired by the law,—leading as a paedagogue to Christ, trained so as to manifest their piety by their blood.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:113
verses.text: "God stood in the congregation of the gods; He judgeth in the midst of the gods".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:114
verses.text: Who are they? Those that are superior to Pleasure, who rise above the passions, who know what they do—the Gnostics, who are greater than the world.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:115
verses.text: "I said, Ye are Gods; and all sons of the Highest".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:116
verses.text: To whom speaks the Lord? To those who reject as far as possible all that is of man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:117
verses.text: And the apostle says, "For ye are not any longer in the flesh, but in the Spirit".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:118
verses.text: And again he says, "Though in the flesh, we do not war after the flesh".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:119
verses.text: "For flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom of God, neither doth corruption inherit incorruption".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:120
verses.text: "Lo, ye shall die like men," the Spirit has said, confuting us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:121
verses.text: We must then exercise ourselves in taking care about those things which fall under the power of the passions, fleeing like those who are truly philosophers such articles of food as excite lust, and dissolute licentiousness in chambering and luxury; and the sensations that tend to luxury, which are a solid reward to others, must no longer be so to us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:122
verses.text: For God's greatest gift is self-restraint.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:123
verses.text: For He Himself has said, "I will neyer leave thee, nor forsake thee," as having judged thee worthy according to the true election.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:124
verses.text: Thus, then, while we attempt piously to advance, we shall have put on us the mild yoke of the Lord from faith to faith, one charioteer driving each of us onward to salvation, that the meet fruit of beatitude may be won.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 14:125
verses.text: "Exercise is" according to Hippocrates of Cos, "not only the health of the body, but of the soul—fearlessness of labours—a ravenous appetite for food".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:1
verses.text: Chapter 21—Opinions of Various Philosophers on the Chief Good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:2
verses.text: Epicurus, in placing happiness in not being hungry, or thirsty, or cold, uttered that godlike word, saying impiously that he would fight in these points even with Father Jove; teaching, as if it were the case of pigs that live in filth and not that of rational philosophers, that happiness was victory.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:3
verses.text: For of those that are ruled by pleasure are the Cyrenaics and Epicurus; for these expressly said that to live pleasantly was the chief end, and that pleasure was the only perfect good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:4
verses.text: Epicurus also says that the removal of pain is pleasure; and says that that is to be preferred, which first attracts from itself to itself, being, that is, wholly in motion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:5
verses.text: Dinomachus and Callipho said that the chief end was for one to do what he could for the attainment and enjoyment of pleasure; and Hieronymus the Peripatetic said the great end was to live unmolested, and that the only final good was happiness; and Diodorus likewise, who belonged to the same sect, pronounces the end to be to live undisturbed and well.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:6
verses.text: Epicurus indeed, and the Cyrenaics, say that pleasure is the first duty; for it is for the sake of pleasure, they say,  that virtue was introduced, and produced pleasure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:7
verses.text: According to the followers of Calliphon, virtue was introduced for the sake of pleasure, but that subsequently, on seeing its own beauty, it made itself equally prized with the first principle, that is, pleasure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:8
verses.text: But the Aristotelians lay it down, that to live in accordance with virtue is the end, but that neither happiness nor the end is reached by every one who has virtue.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:9
verses.text: For the wise man, vexed and involved in involuntary mischances, and wishing gladly on these accounts to flee from life, is neither fortunate nor happy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:10
verses.text: For virtue needs time; for that is not acquired in one day which exists only in the perfect man since, as they say, a child is never happy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:11
verses.text: But human life is a perfect time, and therefore happiness is completed by the three kinds of good things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:12
verses.text: Neither, then, the poor, nor the mean nor even the diseased, nor the slave, can be one of them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:13
verses.text: Again, on the other hand, Zeno the Stoic thinks the end to be living according to virtue; and, Cleanthes, living agreeably to nature in the right exercise of reason, which he held to consist of the selection of things according to nature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:14
verses.text: And Antipatrus, his friend, supposes the end to consist in choosing continually and unswervingly the things which are according to nature, and rejecting those contrary to nature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:15
verses.text: Archedamus, on the other hand, explained the end to be such, that in selecting the greatest and chief things according to nature, it was impossible to overstep it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:16
verses.text: In addition to these, Panaetius pronounced the end to be, to live according to the means given to us by nature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:17
verses.text: And finally, Posidonius said that it was to live engaged in contemplating the truth and order of the universe, and forming himself as he best can, in nothing influenced by the irrational part of his soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:18
verses.text: And some of the later Stoics defined the great end to consist in living agreeably to the constitution of man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:19
verses.text: Why should I mention Aristo? He said that the end was indifference; but what is indifferent simply abandons the indifferent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:20
verses.text: Shall I bring forward the opinions of Herillus? Herillus states the end to be to live according to science.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:21
verses.text: For some think that the more recent disciples of the Academy define the end to be, the steady abstraction of the mind to its own impressions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:22
verses.text: Further, Lycus the Peripatetic used to say that the final end was the true joy of the soul; as Leucimus, that it was the joy it had in what was good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:23
verses.text: Critolaus, also a Peripatetic, said that it was the perfection of a life flowing rightly according to nature, referring to the perfection accomplished by the three kinds according to tradition.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:24
verses.text: We must, however, not rest satisfied with these, but endeavour as we best can to adduce the doctrines laid down on the point by the naturalist; for they say that Anaxagoras of Clazomenae affirmed contemplation and the freedom flowing from it to be the end of life; Heraclitus the Ephesian, complacency.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:25
verses.text: The Pontic Heraclides relates, that Pythagoras taught that the knowledge of the perfection of the numbers was happiness of the soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:26
verses.text: The Abderites also teach the existence of an end.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:27
verses.text: Democritus, in his work On the Chief End, said it was cheerfulness, which he also called well-being, and often exclaims, "For delight and its absence are the boundary of those who have reached full age;" Hecataeus, that it was sufficiency to one's self; Apollodotus of Cyzicum, that it was delectation; as Nausiphanes, that it was undauntedness, for he said that it was this that was called by Democritus imperturbability.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:28
verses.text: In addition to these still, Diotimus declared the end to be perfection of what is good, which he said was termed well-being.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:29
verses.text: Again, Antisthenes, that it was humility.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:30
verses.text: And those called Annicereans, of the Cyrenaic succession, laid down no definite end for the whole of life; but said that to each action belonged, as its proper end, the pleasure accruing from the action.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:31
verses.text: These Cyrenaics reject Epicurus' definition of pleasure, that is the removal of pain, calling that the condition of a dead man; because we rejoice not only on account of pleasures, but companionships and distinctions; while Epicurus thinks that all joy of the soul arises from previous sensations of the flesh.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 15:32
verses.text: Metrodorus, in his book On the Source of Happiness in Ourselves being greater than that which arises from Objects, says: What else is the good of the soul but the sound state of the flesh, and the sure hope of its continuance?.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:1
verses.text: Chapter 22—Plato's Opinion, that the Chief Good Consists in Assimilation to God, and Its Agreement with Scripture.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:2
verses.text: Further, Plato the philosopher says that the end is twofold: that which is communicable, and exists first in the ideal forms themselves, which he also calls "the good;" and that which partakes of it, and receives its likeness from it, as is the case in the men who appropriate virtue and true philosophy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:3
verses.text: Wherefore also Cleanthes, in the second book, On Pleasure, says that Socrates everywhere teaches that the just man and the happy are one and the same, and execrated the first man who separated the just from the useful, as having done an impious thing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:4
verses.text: For those are in truth impious who separate the useful from that which is right according to the law.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:5
verses.text: Plato himself says that happiness  (εὐδαιμονία) is to possess rightly the daemon, and that the ruling faculty of the soul is called the daemon; and he terms happiness (εὐδαιμονία) the most perfect and complete good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:6
verses.text: Sometimes he calls it a consistent and harmonious life, sometimes the highest perfection in accordance with virtue; and this he places in the knowledge of the Good, and in likeness to God, demonstrating likeness to be justice and holiness with wisdom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:7
verses.text: For is it not thus that some of our writers have understood that man straightway on his creation received what is "according to the image," but that what is according "to the likeness" he will receive afterwards on his perfection? Now Plato, teaching that the virtuous man shall have this likeness accompanied with humility, explains the following: "He that humbleth himself shall be exalted".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:8
verses.text: He says, accordingly, in The Laws: "God indeed, as the ancient saying has it, occupying the beginning, the middle, and the end of all things, goes straight through while He goes round the circumference.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:9
verses.text: And He is always attended by Justice, the avenger of those who revolt from the divine law".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:10
verses.text: You see how he connects fear with the divine law.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:11
verses.text: He adds, therefore: "To which he, who would be happy, cleaving, will follow lowly and beautified".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:12
verses.text: Then, connecting what follows these words, and admonishing by fear, he adds: "What conduct, then, is dear and conformable to God? That which is characterized by one word of old date: Like will be dear to like, as to what is in proportion; but things out of proportion are neither dear to one another, nor to those which are in proportion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:13
verses.text: And that therefore he that would be dear to God, must, to the best of his power, become such as He is.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:14
verses.text: And in virtue of the same reason, our self-controlling man is dear to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:15
verses.text: But he that has no self-control is unlike and diverse".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:16
verses.text: In saying that it was an ancient dogma, he indicates the teaching which had come to him from the law.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:17
verses.text: And having in the Theatoetus admitted that evils make the circuit of mortal nature and of this spot, he adds: "Wherefore we must try to flee hence as soon as possible.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:18
