verses.text: For flight is likeness to God as far as possible.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:19
verses.text: And likeness is to become holy and just with wisdom".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:20
verses.text: Speusippus, the nephew of Plato, says that happiness is a perfect state in those who conduct themselves in accordance with nature, or the state of the good: for which condition all men have a desire, but the good only attained to quietude; consequently the virtues are the authors of happiness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:21
verses.text: And Xenocrates the Chalcedonian defines happiness to be the possession of virtue, strictly so called, and of the power subservient to it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:22
verses.text: Then he clearly says, that the seat in which it resides is the soul; that by which it is effected, the virtues; and that of these as parts are formed praiseworthy actions, good habits and dispositions, and motions, and relations; and that corporeal and external objects are not without these.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:23
verses.text: For Polemo, the disciple of Xenocrates, seems of the opinion that happiness is sufficiency of all good things, or of the most and greatest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:24
verses.text: He lays down the doctrine, then, that happiness never exists without virtue; and that virtue, apart from corporeal and external objects, is sufficient for happiness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:25
verses.text: Let these things be so.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:26
verses.text: The contradictions to the opinions specified shall be adduced in due time.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:27
verses.text: But on us it is incumbent to reach the unaccomplished end, obeying the commands—that is, God—and living according to them, irreproachably and intelligently, through knowledge of the divine will; and assimilation as far as possible in accordance with right reason is the end, and restoration to perfect adoption by the Son, which ever glorifies the Father by the great High Priest who has deigned to call us brethren and fellow-heirs.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:28
verses.text: And the apostle, succinctly describing the end, writes in the Epistle to the Romans: "But now, being made free from sin, and become servants to God, ye have your fruit unto holiness, and the end everlasting life".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:29
verses.text: And viewing the hope as twofold—that which is expected, and that which has been received—he now teaches the end to be the restitution of the hope.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:30
verses.text: "For patience," he says, "worketh experience, and experience hope: and hope maketh not ashamed; because the love of God is shed abroad in our hearts by the Holy Spirit that is given to us".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:31
verses.text: On account of which love and the restoration to hope, he says, in another place, "which rest is laid up for us".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:32
verses.text: You will find in Ezekiel the like, as follows: "The soul that sinneth, it shall die.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:33
verses.text: And the man who shall be righteous, and shall do judgment and justice, who has not eaten on the mountains, nor lifted his eyes to the idols of the house of Israel, and hath not defiled his neighbour's wife, and hath not approached to a woman in the time of her uncleanness (for he does not wish the seed of man to be dishonoured), and will not injure a man; will restore the debtor's pledge, and will not take usury; will turn away his hand from wrong; will do true judgment between a man and his neighbour; will walk in my ordinances, and keep my commandments, so as to do the truth; he is righteous, he shall surely live, saith Adonai the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:34
verses.text: Isaiah too, in exhorting him that hath not believed to gravity of life, and the Gnostic to attention, proving that man's virtue and God's are not the same, speaks thus: "Seek the Lord, and on finding Him call on Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:35
verses.text: And when  He shall draw near to you, let the wicked forsake his ways, and the unrighteous man his ways; and let him return to the Lord, and he shall obtain mercy," down to "and your thoughts from my thoughts".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:36
verses.text: "We," then, according to the noble apostle, "wait for the hope of righteousness by faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:37
verses.text: For in Christ neither circumcision availeth anything, nor uncircumcision, but faith which worketh by love".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:38
verses.text: And we desire that every one of you show the same diligence to the full assurance of hope," down to "made an high priest for ever, after the order of Melchizedek".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:39
verses.text: Similarly with Paul "the All-virtuous Wisdom" says, "H, that heareth me shall dwell trusting in hope".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:40
verses.text: For the restoration of hope is called by the same term "hope".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:41
verses.text: To the expression "will dwell" it has most beautifully added "trusting," showing that such an one has obtained rest, having received the hope for which he hoped.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:42
verses.text: Wherefore also it is added, "and shall be quiet, without fear of any evil".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:43
verses.text: And openly and expressly the apostle, in the first Epistle to the Corinthians says, "Be ye followers of me, as also I am of Christ," in order that that may take place.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:44
verses.text: If ye are of me, and I am of Christ, then ye are imitators of Christ, and Christ of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:45
verses.text: Assimilation to God, then, so that as far as possible a man becomes righteous and holy with wisdom he lays down as the aim of faith, and the end to be that restitution of the promise which is effected by faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:46
verses.text: From these doctrines gush the fountains, which we specified above, of those who have dogmatized about "the end".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 16:47
verses.text: But of these enough.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:1
verses.text: Chapter 23—On Marriage.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:2
verses.text: Since pleasure and lust seem to fall under marriage, it must also be treated of.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:3
verses.text: Marriage is the first conjunction of man and woman for the procreation of legitimate children.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:4
verses.text: Accordingly Menander the comic poet says:—  "For the begetting of legitimate children, I give thee my daughter".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:5
verses.text: We ask if we ought to marry; which is one of the points, which are said to be relative.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:6
verses.text: For some must marry, and a man must be in some condition, and he must marry some one in some condition.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:7
verses.text: For every one is not to marry, nor always.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:8
verses.text: But there is a time in which it is suitable, and a person for whom it is suitable, and an age up to which it is suitable.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:9
verses.text: Neither ought every one to take a wife, nor is it every woman one is to take, nor always, nor in every way, nor inconsiderately.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:10
verses.text: But only he who is in certain circumstances, and such an one and at such time as is requisite, and for the sake of children, and one who is in every respect similar, and who does not by force or compulsion love the husband who loves her.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:11
verses.text: Hence Abraham, regarding his wife as a sister, says, "She is my sister by my father, but not by my mother; and she became my wife," teaching us that children of the same mothers ought not to enter into matrimony.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:12
verses.text: Let us briefly follow the history.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:13
verses.text: Plato ranks marriage among outward good things, providing for the perpetuity of our race, and handing down as a torch a certain perpetuity to children's children.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:14
verses.text: Democritus repudiates marriage and the procreation of children, on account of the many annoyances thence arising, and abstractions from more necessary things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:15
verses.text: Epicurus agrees, and those who place good in pleasure, and in the absence of trouble and pain.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:16
verses.text: According to the opinion of the Stoics, marriage and the rearing of children are a thing indifferent; and according to the Peripatetics, a good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:17
verses.text: In a word, these, following out their dogmas in words, became enslaved to pleasures; some using concubines, some mistresses, and the most youths.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:18
verses.text: And that wise quaternion in the garden with a mistress, honoured pleasure by their acts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:19
verses.text: Those, then, will not escape the curse of yoking an ass with an ox, who, judging certain things not to suit them, command others to do them, or the reverse.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:20
verses.text: This Scripture has briefly showed, when it says, "What thou hatest, thou shalt not do to another".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:21
verses.text: But they who approve of marriage say, Nature has adapted us for marriage, as is evident from the structure of our bodies, which are male and female.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:22
verses.text: And they constantly proclaim that command, "Increase and replenish".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:23
verses.text: And though this is the case, yet it seems to them shameful that man, created by God, should be more licentious than the irrational creatures, which do not mix with many licentiously, but with one of the same species, such as pigeons and ringdoves, and creatures like them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:24
verses.text: Furthermore, they say, "The childless man fails in the perfection which is according to nature, not having substituted his proper successor in his place.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:25
verses.text: For he is perfect that has produced from himself his like, or rather, when he sees that he has produced the same; that is, when that which is begotten attains to the same nature with him who begat".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:26
verses.text: Therefore we must by all means marry, both for our country's sake,  for the succession of children, and as far as we are concerned, the perfection of the world; since the poets also pity a marriage half-perfect and childless, but pronounce the fruitful one happy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:27
verses.text: But it is the diseases of the body that principally show marriage to be necessary.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:28
verses.text: For a wife's care and the assiduity of her constancy appear to exceed the endurance of all other relations and friends, as much as to excel them in sympathy; and most of all, she takes kindly to patient watching.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:29
verses.text: And in truth, according to Scripture, she is a needful help.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:30
verses.text: The comic poet then, Menander, while running down marriage, and yet alleging on the other side its advantages, replies to one who had said:—  "I am averse to the thing, For you take it awkwardly".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:31
verses.text: Then he adds:—  "You see the hardships and the things which annoy you in it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:32
verses.text: But you do not look on the advantages".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:33
verses.text: And so forth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:34
verses.text: Now marriage is a help in the case of those advanced in years, by furnishing a spouse to take care of one, and by rearing children of her to nourish one's old age.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:35
verses.text: "For to a man after death his children bring renown, Just as corks bear the net, Saving the fishing-line from the deep".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:36
verses.text: according to the tragic poet Sophocles.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:37
verses.text: Legislators, moreover, do not allow those who are unmarried to discharge the highest magisterial offices.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:38
verses.text: For instance, the legislator of the Spartans imposed a fine not on bachelorhood only, but on monogamy, and late marriage, and single life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:39
verses.text: And the renowned Plato orders the man who has not married to pay a wife's maintenance into the public treasury, and to give to the magistrates a suitable sum of money as expenses.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:40
verses.text: For if they shall not beget children, not having married, they produce, as far as in them lies, a scarcity of men, and dissolve states and the world that is composed of them, impiously doing away with divine generation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:41
verses.text: It is also unmanly and weak to shun living with a wife and children.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:42
verses.text: For of that of which the loss is an evil, the possession is by all means a good; and this is the case with the rest of things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:43
verses.text: But the loss of children is, they say, among the chiefest evils: the possession of children is consequently a good thing; and if it be so, so also is marriage.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:44
verses.text: It is said:—  "Without a father there never could be a child, And without a mother conception of a child could not be.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:45
verses.text: Marriage makes a father, as a husband a mother".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:46
verses.text: Accordingly Homer makes a thing to be earnestly prayed for:—  "A husband and a house;"  yet not simply, but along with good agreement.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:47
verses.text: For the marriage of other people is an agreement for indulgence; but that of philosophers leads to that agreement which is in accordance with reason, bidding wives adorn themselves not in outward appearance, but in character; and enjoining husbands not to treat their wedded wives as mistresses, making corporeal wantonness their aim; but to take advantage of marriage for help in the whole of life, and for the best self-restraint.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:48
verses.text: Far more excellent, in my opinion, than the seeds of wheat and barley that are sown at appropriate seasons, is man that is sown, for whom all things grow; and those seeds temperate husbandmen ever sow.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:49
verses.text: Every foul and polluting practice must therefore be purged away from marriage; that the intercourse of the irrational animals may not be cast in our teeth, as more accordant with nature than human conjunction in procreation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:50
verses.text: Some of these, it must be granted, desist at the time in which they are directed, leaving creation to the working of Providence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:51
verses.text: By the tragedians, Polyxena, though being murdered, is described nevertheless as having, when dying, taken great care to fall decently,—  "Concealing what ought to be hid from the eyes of men".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:52
verses.text: Marriage to her was a calamity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:53
verses.text: To be subjected, then, to the passions, and to yield to them, is the extremest slavery; as to keep them in subjection is the only liberty.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:54
verses.text: The divine Scripture accordingly says, that those who have transgressed the commandments are sold to strangers, that is, to sins alien to nature, till they return and repent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:55
verses.text: Marriage, then, as a sacred image, must be kept pure from those things which defile it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:56
verses.text: We are to rise from our slumbers with the Lord, and retire to sleep with thanksgiving and prayer,—  "Both when you sleep, and when the holy light comes,"  confessing the Lord in our whole life; possessing piety in the soul, and extending self-control to the body.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:57
verses.text: For it is pleasing to God to lead decorum from the tongue to our actions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:58
verses.text: Filthy speech is the way to effrontery; and the end of both is filthy conduct.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:59
verses.text: Now that the Scripture counsels marriage, and allows no release from the union, is expressly contained in the law, "Thou shalt not put away thy wife, except for the cause of fornication;" and it regards as fornication, the marriage of those separated while the other is alive.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:60
verses.text: Not to deck and adorn herself beyond what is becoming, renders a wife free of calumnious suspicion, while she devotes herself assiduously to prayers and supplications; avoiding frequent departures from the house, and shutting herself up as far as possible from the view of all not related to her, and deeming housekeeping of more consequence than impertinent trifling.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:61
verses.text: "He that taketh a woman that has been put away," it is said, "committeth adultery; and if one puts away his wife, he makes her an adulteress," that is, compels her to commit adultery.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:62
verses.text: And not only is he who puts her away guilty of this, but he who takes her, by giving to the woman the opportunity of sinning; for did he not take her, she would return to her husband.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:63
verses.text: What, then, is the law? In order to check the impetuosity of the passions, it commands the adulteress to be put to death, on being convicted of this; and if of priestly family, to be committed to the flames.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:64
verses.text: And the adulterer also is stoned to death, but not in the same place, that not even their death may be in common.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:65
verses.text: And the law is not at variance with the Gospel, but agrees with it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:66
verses.text: How should it be otherwise, one Lord being the author of both? She who has committed fornication liveth in sin, and is dead to the commandments; but she who has repented, being as it were born again by the change in her life, has a regeneration of life; the old harlot being dead, and she who has been regenerated by repentance having come back again to life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:67
verses.text: The Spirit testifies to what has been said by Ezekiel, declaring, "I desire not the death of the sinner, but that he should turn".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:68
verses.text: Now they are stoned to death; as through hardness of heart dead to the law which they believed not.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:69
verses.text: But in the case of a priestess the punishment is increased, because "to whom much is given, from him shall more be required".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:70
verses.text: Let us conclude this second book of the Stromata at this point, on account of the length and number of the chapters.

verses.text: 1 - note , p)  The admirable comments of Stier on the Greeks, who said to Philip, "We would see Jesus," seem to me vindicated by the history of the Gospel, and by the part which the Greeks were called to take in its propagation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:75
verses.text: Clement seems to me the man of Providence, who gives rich significance to "the corn of wheat," and its multiplication in Gentile discipleship.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:76
verses.text: And in this I am a convert to Stier's view, against my preconceptions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:77
verses.text: That the Greeks who were at Jerusalem at the Passover were other than Hellenistic Jews, or Greek proselytes, always seemed to me improbable; but, more and more, I discover a design in this narrative, which seems to me thoroughly sustained by the history of the Gentile churches, which were Greek everywhere originally, and for the use of which the Septuagint had been prepared in the providence of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:78
verses.text: To say nothing of the New-Testament Scriptures, the whole symbolic and liturgic system of the early Christians and all the Catholic councils which were Greek in their topography, language, and legislation, confirm the sublime thought which Stier has elucidated.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:79
verses.text: "The Pharisees said, The world is gone after him; and there were certain Greeks," etc.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:81
verses.text: Jesus is told of their desire to see him; and he answers, "The hour is come that the Son of man should be glorified;" and he goes on to speak of his death as giving life to the world.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:82
verses.text: I feel grateful to Stier for his bold originality in  treating the subject; and I trust others will find that it invests the study of the ante-Nicene Fathers with a fresh interest, and throws back from their writings a peculiar reflex light on the New-Testament Scriptures themselves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:88
verses.text: The eighteenth chapter of this book must also be kept in view if we would do full justice to the true position of Clement, who recognises nothing in heathen philosophy as true wisdom, save as it flows from God, in Moses, and through the Hebrew Church.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:89
verses.text: That Greek philosophy, so viewed, did lead to Christ, and that this great principle is recognised in the apostolic teachings, seems to me indisputable.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:95
verses.text: For this, and Neander's qualifying comment, see Kaye, p Clement is far from charging Basilides, personally, with an immoral life, or from lending his sanction to impurity; but a study of the Gnostic sects, with whom our Alexandrian doctor was forced to contend, will show that they were introducing, under the pretence of Christianity, such abominations as made their defeat and absolute overthrow a matter of life and death for the Church.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:96
verses.text: To let such teachers be confounded with Christians, was to neutralize the very purpose for which the Church existed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:97
verses.text: Now, it was in the deadly grapple with such loathsome errorists, that the idea of "Catholic orthodoxy" became so precious to the primitive faithful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:98
verses.text: They were forced to make even the heathen comprehend the existence of that word-wide confederation of churches already explained, and to exhibit their Scriptural creed and purity of discipline, in the strongest contrast with these pestilent "armies of the aliens," who were neither Gnostics nor Christians indeed, much less Catholic or Orthodox teachers and believers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:99
verses.text: Now, if in dealing with counterfeits Clement was obliged to meet them on their own grounds, and defeat them on a plan, at once intelligible to the heathen, and enabling all believers to "fight the good fight of faith" successfully, we must concede that he knew better than we can, what was suited to the Alexandrian schools, their intellect, and their false mysticism.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:100
verses.text: His works were a great safeguard to those who came after him; though they led to the false system of exposition by which Origen so greatly impaired his services to the Church, and perhaps to other evils, which, in the issue, shook the great patriarchate of Alexandria to its foundations.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:101
verses.text: It is curious to trace the influence of Clement, through Tertullian and St.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book II.2 17:103
verses.text: The mysticism of Fénelon as well, may be traced, more than is generally credited, to the old Alexandrian school, which was itself the product of some of the most subtle elements of our nature, sanctified, but not wholly controlled, by the wisdom that is from above.
